hello and welcome to our tour; my name is winston hogfeller the third, your guide.  of course were here to explore and appreciate this grand edifice of brewing: the renouned castle alesmith ipa. so if everyone is quite ready, well begin. approaching, youll notice that the bottle itself has a minimalist facade, with its plain white and strictly utilitarian block letters forged in the helvetica font from the mountains of switzerland. the brooding exterior is highly misleading, even paradoxical.  i would advise here only cursory photography to save your film for the famous and expansive pour. indeed, here it comes, with trumpets, banners and royal pomp (much gasping ascending to spontaneous applause). please stand back, the foam will bloom to extraordinary heights. yes there it is in the goblet! (sound of many cameras shooting).  an inverted rotunda after the fashion of st. peters: interlocking panels of pure amber and aztec gold with enormous and flamboyant flying buttresses of foam-- at once seemingly snatched from and mingling with the clouds and heavens. but wait! do look more closely overhead and observe the exquisite lacing, an almost dizzying filigree of ivory, and notice as well the more subtle inlay of tiny gems of particulate matter throughout the interior. they do seem to defy gravity. lets move along to the aroma, and here youre entering a lush emerald city of green hops. the architect had a penchant obviously for hops, and created the perfect halls and grottos to serve up whatever state banquet was called for, done in the verdant tones of piney saw dust, green banana peel, sage, toffee and gingersnap. during this period in the evolution of the great american lupulin palaces of course there was incredible competition among designers to create this kind of rococo stylistic hyperbole. and thats seen here in the flavor, where the grand design comes to fruition. the great expense of the tonnage of hops is quite immeasurable, all the more remarkable in that it was done by hand-- and by artisans receiving but modest remuneration. on your left are orchard fruits, delicately wrought, and on your right, the bold imperial bitters in full regalia. now, watch your head as we descend into the wet catacombs of full body, carved out of living malts, structurally immense with pillars of caramel under arcs of subtle honey sweetness. walk this way please, stay together everyone. finally, after gurgling along a hop "randall" aqueduct spanning the entire grounds, the flavor drops at last into this splendid courtyard fountain. i say. just remarkable i think youll agree. this concludes our tour, thank you, and visitors are now free to relax in the hospitality area where everyone will receive a very handsome complimentary buzz. (final applause, much excited chatter punctuated with the mingled sounds of search dog sniffing and rapid swallowing).

Bottle  Pours a hazy amber with a good off white frothy head.  Good lasting with excellent lacing.  Aroma is hoppy spruce with hints of leaves and molasses.  Just about the perfect carbonation that a beer could be.  Very smooth with a slight oily texture.  Has a great duration with an excellent aftertaste.  This has great blending.  A wonderful IPA.  It makes me want to move to California so I can get more of it.  The only negative to this beer is that I cant get it easily in Pennsylvania. Just awesome.

Bottle.  Poured a very slightly hazy medium golden with a well-retained white head... lovely intricate lacing the whole way down.  Heaps and buckets of Pac NW hoppage (pine and grapefruit) in the nose balanced by a substantial caramel malt presence.  Full and seductive flavors similar to the nose... freshly-squeezed grapefruit, Spruce needles, smooth caramel, and mild warmth from the alcohol.  Bitterness was average for the style, just the right level considering the other components in here.  Moderate carbonation gave it a creamy feel across the middle.  Crisp Cascade finish left a lasting impression.  Phenominal brew!

A bland bottle desing is not representative of what is inside.  Thanks to Firemoose 415 for sharing.  Pours a cloudy amber color with some sediment.  Soapy off-white head that lingers.  Hops and pine dominate the aroma.  Taste is a well-balanced combination of hops, malts, and some pine with a slightly dry finish.

22 oz bottle, via fordest.  Pours a dark copper with a small fizzy white head.  A few small streams of carbonation rising from the depths.  Nice aggressive citric hop aroma, some toasted and caramel malt below.  Hops focused flavor for sure, citrusy grapefruity goodness.  Plenty of malt in the background to balance this guy out.  Not over-the-top in anything, just a very clean and crisp flavor without flaws.  No indication on the flavor that this is over 7% ABV.  Light to medium bodied with moderate and extremely fine-bubbled carbonation.  A classic example of an IPA, packed with flavor without being in your face.

Courtesy of fordest.  Bottle. Aroma very pleasant waffe of citric and pine hops.  Poured a nice lighter amber with a thick white head.  Flavor was just a treat, a good punch of the hops and light fruit character really combine well.  Palate was nice, medium bodied that kept you wanting more.  Overall one of the tastiest IPAs Ive had.

Bottle at Enniskillens tasting  Pours a nice, mellow amber with clinging lace.  Aroma is a round ball of grapefruit.  Flavor is a rush of pine and grapefruit.  Palate is sticky and slippery.  Damn good IPA; one of the best out there.  I MUST HAVE MORE.
user_location: Ugly, Hot, and Humid Spring, Texas, USA

text: Huge chewy hops, full bodied for the style with a dense orange color that is dark in the middle of the glass.  Malt presence to balance everythiing out is substantial as well.  Much preferred to their IIPA.
very balanced ipa that coats your mouth in sweet hoppy nectar for a chewy after taste that last a while......a little oily.....

Hazed orange body with a frickin huge white head. Sweet malty aroma at first that had me grasping to describe butterscotch or is it toffee or is it moon pies, yeah its banana moon pies, cool I dont know if Ive ever had banana moon pies in a aroma before, Ill have to search through my ratings, but this is definitely banana moon pie aroma.  I dont know the hops used but they show up in the nose too, sugary grass and other goodies. Strong malt sweetness that surprises me then I taste the hops. Which are grassy and slick. I expected this to be over the top smack you in the face hop juice, but it is an easy drinking balanced beer that is easy to enjoy. A bit more malt flavor than I expected from an IPA from the west coast but not bad at all. There is something subverting this and it is a tannic unsweet iced tea flavor in the finish. The sweet graham cracker and marshmallow flavor is nice but I dont like the hop profile much.  Grassy peanut hop flavor that is not quite my cup o tea. A touch of pine is there also but it doesnt please me that much.  A nice pleasant beer nonetheless. 
Ap-4 ar- 8 tas-6 pal-3 ov-13

Bottle, from my wonderful daughter who carried it on the plane from California.  Not much aroma, great appearance.  Looks and tastes like a great IPA.  Hops are prounced, but not too bitter...balanced well by malt.  Overall flavor is complex...fairly high alcohol but very drinkable.
nice beer! has a pleasing taste to the palate with the right amount of alcohol, making it is go-to beer for most occasions. flavor is just strong enough.

22oz bottle poured a golden color with a great frothy off-white head.  Aroma of pine with a hint of vanilla.  Nice hoppy flavors of citrus and pine but not too hoppy.  A very well balanced IPA.  Definitely a top 3 IPA I have tasted.

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2010 22oz Bottle.  Crisp aroma, earthy with texture.  Flavor is bright and full. Good IPA. Balanced and not overly hopped.  Something I can see myself returning too. 
Rerated 8/11/10: up from 4 to 4.3. This is just delicious and consistently great IPA.

MN Winter Get Together, 2006:  Gold color with little head.  Strong aroma of citrusy hops.  This oddly switches to a more earthy and floral hop in the flavor, more reminiscent of EK Goldings.  Bone dry finish with just enough malt to balance out the hops, yet not overshadow them.  Damn fine.
What a great ipa.  It has the perfect balance of bitter, herbal hops and light fruit aromas an flavors.  Some orange and grapefruit in the aroma.

Lovely pine resin color with a very thin, healthy, off-white head.  Initial nose is very sappy and smells of burned cedar.  The texture is surprisingly smooth and sweet, and it doesnt contain the trademark pucker of other IPAs.  Sweet, dried apricots are followed by luscious grapefruit before being finished off by a fresh sage resin.  Very pleasing IPA, overall.
Thick and smooth, pours orange.  Very tasty IPA.  Pine and citrusy hoppy flavors, and also malty flavors.  Kind of bitter but not overwhelming.

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2009 Appearance: Pours a nice deep gold/amber that has a nice fluffy thick white head that dissapates easily and leaves a heavy lace. 
Aroma: Balanced citrus with a hint of pine and very smooth hop note.
Flavor profile: A smooth, very hoppy but balanced flavor with a little cinnamon and honey make up the initial flavor profile with a nice malty sweet aftertaste that also hints of vanilla. Big mouthfeel and flavor that is very balanced.
Palate: Thick and smooth, goes down very nicely, very quenching and very rich.
Overall: A supremely balanced, hoppy, smooth IPA. This is a beer that truely shows how incredible a restrained, well balanced IPA can be.
The best IPA I  have ever had. Huge citrus hop aroma balanced by a powerful malt flavor. Excellent.
Winter bomber. Big, hoppy aroma, very fresh, lots of pine and grapefruit. Similar taste with a nice malt touch at the end. Very pleasing and relaxing, quaffable and delicious.

01.16.06  Bomber.  Copper-amber colored with rocky beige head that lasts and laces in gobs of sticky foam.  Aroma is pungent with citrus blossom and pine resin; its hard to find much malt in the aroma behind all that hoppy punch, but there are some caramel hints.  The palate is sticky, almost gooey with luscious resin.  Its medium-full and rather coating for an ipa with lingering alcohol in the nose.  Flavor is bolstered by more bitterness and grapefruit pith than bargained for, none of it unwelcome, however theres some bready acidity that feels awkward.  Well, thats easy enough to ignore by focusing on the yummy hops and enjoying the pleasingly dry finish.  For a regular ipa, this beer is pretty substantial.
Poured with a tall fluffy head that didnt go away.  Tasted of hops, citrus and grapefruit, with a crisp but also thick mouth.  Good  bitterness but not over the top.  One of the best IPAs Ive had.

(22 oz bottle: $3.39 at BevMo in La Jolla, CA) I decided to do a rerate on this beer, just to see if I liked it any more than I did 13 months ago, when I thought it was quite good but didnt love it.  The BevMo I work at just got this in today, and it was still cold when I was replentishing the empty AleSmith IPA shelf space, so I put one in the cooler for myself to drink tonight (ah, the single best benefit of working at a retail liquor store!).  And my God, Im now convinced that I must have rated a bottle that was not in tip-top shape because this beer is so freaking fresh and delicious, I have to think it was bottled within the last week.  Frankly, this beer is more flavorful, supremely malty and intensely hoppy than many Imperial IPAs Ive tasted.  Huge citrus hoppiness tastes exceptionally fresh and provides a very strong bitterness from sip to finish, but the sweet malts just laugh out loud at the thought of playing second fiddle.  As hoppy as this beer is, its still extremely well balanced by the sweet malt, tasty fruitiness and tea-like herbal character.  Full bodied, very coating on the palate, bordering on sticky.  Solid carbonation and crisp hoppiness keep the palate refreshed.  Golden amber in color with modest haze from bottle conditioning.  The off-white head is very active on the pour, rising to probably an inch and a half, and thats with a reasonably careful pour.  Retention is magnificent, never fading below a quarter inch, and lacing decorates much of the glass in large, dense and thick patches.  With all the incredible beers AleSmith puts out in their 750 ml bottles, its easy to overlook their "ordinary" beers in bombers, but the IPA is just incredible.  Has to be one of the very best IPAs in the world!!

22 oz bomber at the 2005 beer exchange.  I love all IPAs that are done well and this one is, well... done very well.  Clear and dark golden to orange on the pour with a nice fluffy head to help emit that great grapefruit and piney nose.  Nice balance in this, but not a really overpowering, knock the hell out of you beer that I expected from the ratings that I read.  Dont get me wrong, this is a good beer, but the Yulesmith from Alesmith kicks it in the butt!  I liked this as it had a nice warm mouthfeel with decent body and nice carbonation.  Good brew, just not as good as some other IPAs out there.
This is a ridiculous IPA.  So hoppy and so fruity.  I wish I lived in southern california year round.  Maybe the best straight up IPA I have ever had.  I prefer it to stone and bells two hearted.
"Poured a nice light amber color. Had a huge head which lasted throughout, and laced well. Typical IPA smell and taste grapefruit and hops. This one was good."

Very floral nose, like violets and lillies of the valley, some sweet caramel and vanilla accents. Hazy orange/copper color, with a slight white head. 
Quite citrusy, piney flavor, a bit too dry for the marked bitterness of it, but as a study in C-hops, its rocking.
Tasted on draft @ San Diego Brewing.  Nice, foamy head with good retention.  Exactly what you would expect here- a damn good, drinkable West Coast IPA.

[on tap at Georges at the cove]
Clear, soft, reddish copper with clingy seafoam top.  Diacetyl butterscoth and caramely aroma.  Nice butterscotch-caramel flavour as well with lots of fruity esters: apple, pear, peach.  Medium bitterness.  Medium body, smooth, moderate carbonation.

Rather typical looking golden color, slightly hazy, with a small white head. The aroma burst out with citrusy hops and something I can only describe as intense sweet/sour apple. The flavor was more of the extreme citrus tone siwht a gentle sweetness that rounded out the aftertaste perfectly...this is one of the best tasting IPAs Ive ever had! The feel was slightly soft, but still had a certain amount of crispness in the finish.

I had this in a 20 oz bottle. The smell is of grapefruit and pine hops. The color is a nice amber/red.  The consistency is nice a thick for an ipa. The flavor is full and balanced. This would be a great session beer if it were available around here.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2006 Bottle from Hi Times. Pours orange, with a nice white head. West cost floral aroma of citrus and pine. Flavors of orange, caramel, and grapfruit from the hops, nicely offset by the malt. Very resiny in the mouth. Finish is dry and yeasty, and the acidity lingers on the throat. A very good IPA, but I like Bells Two Hearted a tad better. At least in the bottle

Pours coppery with a large frothy head.  Smells of citrus, pine and summer flowers.  Taste is orangey with nice pine undertones.  Some nice dark chocolate and pepper notes creep in as the beer warms.  Mouthfeel is tingly and thick.  Finish is strong and lasting.

UPDATED: NOV 3, 2007 2005 bomber consumed on 12/3/05 and 12/4/05.  I also had a bottle of it about 4 months ago, but I didnt want to review that one as it was almost syrupy and quite resinous/pine sappy.  Even the 4 months of aging in my refridgerator has helped mellow this one out.  Dont get me wrong, its well malted, but it was just too syrupy and sweet with too much acid when fresh.  Pours a deep, golden-amber, kind of a canteloupe melon color, though quite brilliant with plenty of bottle conditioned bubbles creating a dense and creamy large off-white head that is retained at cover and laces lightly.  Aroma has tons of grapefruit, pine resin and plenty of floral, green hop freshness.  Light juicy fruits apparent as well.  Hints of honey and caramel in the background create a well-balanced and highly aromatic aroma.  Flavor begins with plenty of pine resin, oranges, toasted malt notes, and a sweet caramel-chocolate note.  Kind of like the orange flavored chocolate I had for breakfast.  Herbs and leafy green hops, with a high amount of bitterness.  Spectacular mouthfeel, creamy through and through, with tight carbonation and a chewy substantiality to the body.  Alcohol is not apparent.  High amount of yeast drying on the very end (end of bottle) and a moderate amount of acidity lingers on the palate, but so does plenty of citric hop flavor and light melanoidins.  While not significanly unique from many other West Coast IPAs, the mouthfeel is perfectly executed.

Mmmm....big fat hop nose that never quits - floral and piney. Orange color, foamy head. Sweet honey-ish malt based gets quickly overrun by a tight sharp hop bitter. Medium body, good balance. Aggressive for sure, but not uncontrolled.

Our 2005-Gobble-Gobble Beer! Thank god my Brother in Law and his girlfriend like wine more ;-) To say it with the Brewers words "Its pretty awesome". Dark orange color with a nice silky layer of a head on top. Intense pine and grapefruit nose. Some yeast in the taste first and then going more sharp with pine and flowers in the taste.. Round though and very silky.

Hazed clean yellow pour, topped with a sweet finger of foamy fine head. Aroma is a bashing of west coast hops, all mingled into glorious grapefruit, floral and pine. Hops delicious, but not overwhelming, well balanced somewhat surprisginly with a sweet clean sugar malt in the background. Finish is tart, hop dry and lingering of potpourri. A fantastic IPA! About to be paired with some spicy Indian food. Thanks to my westcoast connection!

Thanks to sick_boy282 for this IPA! Pours a bit darker than most of this style, a hazy dark gold with almost no head to speak of. Nose is hops and citrus, with some pine. Flavors of pink grapefruit and a touch of pine. Not a whole lot of bitter, which is fine by me. Finishes light and clean. VERY nice brew!
65 cl bottle. Yeast in bottom. Golden little unclear colour. Very extreme hoppy aroma with notes of flower. Wonderful balance hoppy IPA. Very tasteful and powerful.

22oz. Opening a big hit of citrusy grapefruit strikes your nostrils. Pours a dark orange color with a foamy white head. nose gets more piney hops, light sweetness, and less grapefruit and citrus then the bottle sniff. Flavors of big , piney, citrusy hops fill your mouth. Very nice bitterness in the finish, very refreshing.

Bottle. This IPA reminded me a lot of Stones, which might be why I enjoyed it so much. The first and last tastes were hops. I noticed a hint of citrus and pine, though I was definately more intrigued by the intense hops flavor. This IPA was almost creamy in its mouthfeel - it was silky, very good. Definately worthwhile.

UPDATED: NOV 15, 2005 Without question this is the best IPA I have ever had.  Like a bitter Grapefruit rind perfect as far as the balance between the  hops and sweetness.  Elusive as far as finding this fine brew.  Its hard to get a hold of and if you find it grab it!!!!
Poured a hazy golden orange color with a nice head.  Nice citrus aroma with a hint of pine.  Very, very tasty.  Very strong hoppy flavor.  Wow.  One of the finest IPAs Ive had.  Excellent.

The best thing about this brew is the aroma. It is really FRESH. I mostly catch the citrus smells of grapefruit but there is definitely some pine in there as well. Big big nose that cant be beat. Goes down smooth and easy. Hard to believe the alc %, its so easy going down.
hazy golden, huge off white head.  floral nose w/ note of grapefruit.  very hoppy and fruity.  over the top hopping, but drinkable.  actually, its damn tasty.

Pours golden-orange with a small, frothy head.  Floral scents with fruity overtones come out of the hoppy aroma.  Thinner-bodied than it appears, it starts light and finishes light.  Bitter buit not notably so for an IPA.  Not very malty, and tastes somewhat salty.  I think that the aroma is more interesting than the taste.  Would enjoy more if there was more balance.

Cool bottle design, plus Im loving this whole bomber thing. Pours with quite a bit of carbonation and forms a big head which becomes incredibly thick and stays about an inch thick to the bottom of the glass. Light amber colour, dead clear. Another great-looking beer (for a great-looking fella!) Raw, piney, slightly vegetal hop aroma with rich, fresh, caramelly malt and a definite vanilla character. Very faint tropical fruit and black pepper. I think the hop aroma could be a little fresher, but otherwise it smells great. Initial flavour of really thick malt - again its very fresh, fairly sweet, caramelly, buttery with a bit of toastiness at the end as it gives way to an earthy, vegetal, artichokey hop flavour and a good clean bitterness. Its a touch worty and theres a bit of alcohol late. Tastes a bit hoppier with the yeast in the glass. Its a lot like Emersons APA only this tastes fresher, though I still cant help but feel that the hop character is a little muted. Its also too thick and malty to be really drinkable. Really good stuff, but it needs more hops (with less vegetabley flavour) to be my ultimate IPA.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, blankboy, jerc & gregclow - courtesy of HogTownHarry.  Big hop and orange peel aroma.  I had a rough day and this aroma alone relieved the stress of it (new slogan "Alesmith IPA: Relieves Stress" could work I think).  Fresh and pine like as well.  Dark yellow pour, thick like head (the beer looks thin).  Creamy, frothy mouthfeel.  Wonderful hop taste, with more hints of orange.  I wish it had just a tad more body, but that is getting pretty picky.  A wonderful IPA, thank you Harry!

Poured a hazy orange with a small long lasting off-white head.  Aroma of citrusy and piney hops hit first with a good amount of sweet malt underneath.  Caramel and dough.  Flavor of caramel, no hops, no caramel, no hops.  Flavor goes back and forth malt to hops all the way through the long finish.  The tail is all hops and nice warmth.  Medium to full body.  This has everything.  Great aroma, great flavor, great balance, and great mouthfeel.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, blankboy, jerc & tupalev - courtesy of HogTownHarry. Slightly hazy orange-amber with a small white head. Fresh & inviting hop aroma - pine, spruce & orange. Soft mouthfeel. Beautiful flavour - lots of hops, of course, but lots of complexity behind it. The sample was good, but not enough to get everything out of this beer.  Im heading to San Diego in a couple of weeks, and I think Ill be grabbing a bottle or two of this it order to get the full experience.

A wonderful West Coast IPA.  Fresh, sticky, kind-bud hop aroma.  Coppery amber, slightly cloudy pour with a bone white head over top it.  Flavor is amazing.  Wonderful sweet malt backbone with plenty of caramel sugar flavors in ite behind a monstrous Pine hop profile.  Wish it came out here normally.

Bottle shared with HogTownHarry, GregClow, jerc & tupalev -- courtesy of HogTownHarry. Pours a cloudy orange with a large rocky white head. The aroma is fan-friggin-tastic! Sweet, fresh hops with some citrus -- thats it, and its close to perfection. The taste is also notable for its fresh, fresh, fresh hop taste -- (insert Homer drooling sound here) -- with some citrus in the finish. It is also close to perfection. Medium body and surprisingly not as bitter as youd think -- its just right. Wow, thanks HogTownHarry for sharing one of the best beers Ive ever had. Time to get me more of these! Did I mention this was close to perfection?

UPDATED: MAR 19, 2006 Bottle (650ml) - Shared with blankboy, GregClow, jerc and tupalev - courtesy of yours truly.  Slightly hazy maber-gold pour, big off-white rocky head.  Aroma is spruce-pine resiny freshfreshfresh hops, lso lemon zest, some sweet malt and fresh cream, some fruit.  Taste - high, fresh hops - different kinds, including cascade - enough malt for some balancing sweetness, plenty of piney-resiny-citrus too - very smooth, with a long but not harsh fresh hoppy finish.  Mouthfeel is tingly - all those hops! - lively and a little astringent - finishes longer as it warms, but still smooth.  In a word: "great" - and Im not a hop-head.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2007 December 2006. New Years Eve, shared with Mabel, bottle courtesy of HogtownHarry. Orangey amber body with a big fluffy off white head (4+). Massive citrus aroma of grapefruit, tangerines, and lemon seeds. Flavour is dominated by citrusy hops, grapefruit, with light notes of resin. Tart lemon and citrus rind in the finish lingers. Malt is an afterthought - I remember there being more but perhaps I am mistaken. Alcohol starts to become a bit noticable as it gets warm (8+) Slightly more full than average palate is just right for the beer. Awesome! Just a touch more malt would make this damn near perfect for my tastebuds. 10/4+/8+/4/18-19 - 4.6

August 2005. Bottle. Orange body with a good size bubbly white head. Big pine resin hops dominate the aroma with mildly leafy notes as well. Quite bitter with some malt shyly offering support. Lots of chewy resin throughout. Barely noticeable lemon in both the start and finish. Medium body is awesome on the tongue. Hoppy hand lingers in its grasp on the back of your throat. Delicious! Many thanks Harry. 8/4/9/4/18 - 4.3

Medium hoppy aroma, hint of citrus. Almost the same coloring as the Yulesmith, though it has a much smaller head. Nice lacing on the glass. Flavor is warming, hoppy, yet subtle. Bitterness is subdued, but still present. Mouthfeel is thinner than the Yulesmith, but still substantial.
Full bodied, creamy texture with warm coppery flavor.  Slightly bitter but very clean finish.  rich foamy head that takes its time when settling down.

Bottle courtesy of radiomgb and DarkElf. Excellent IPA, copper color, touch of haze and a full foamy head. Full grapefruit aroma, decent malt to match. Nice malty start followed by a healthy dose of west coast hops. Medium to full bodied, smooth and round, bitter finish. HIgh quality stuff. Ill accept your beer anytime if you throw in stuff like this!
fantastic ipa.  very smooth and suttle hop taste that will knock you on your butt!  Pours a beautiful golden amber color with an aroma to match.  This is a one great IPA!

22 oz bottle:  Light amber w/ a lasting medium sized white head.  Grassy and lemony hop aroma @ first that becomes herbal & grapefruity w/ some toasted & bready malt.  Very little caramel@ first, moderately fruity(mostly from hops).  well balanced, throughout, but finish & aftertaste, as well as initial flavor are of citrusy hop w/ some hints of bitterness mid palate into the finish as it warms.  toasted malt but still very little caramel, and a bit more pale ale flavored in regards to bitterness.  Medium body, low carbonation, dry m/f as expected, wll hidden alc.  Good as IPAs go, not great, but Im quite certain its not worth the 9.00 I paid for the bottle when everyone else is around 5.00!!!!
A very nice citrusy/floral aroma.  A deep brown color and nice light brown head.  A citrusy taste and nice finish.

22 oz bomber.  Pours a light copperish caramel color with a fine thick white head.  Smells like pine needles and hops.  Has a very citrusy taste with a piney aftertaste.  An excellent IPA.  Very similar to a Stone IPA.

Transparent gold in color with some tiny cloistered bubble colonies breaking everywhere at the surface - its like looking down into a volcano.  Nice nectarine, grapefruit and apricot aroma.  Flavor leads in as crisp with hops placating the palate from the get-go.  A hops crescendo rises to a bitter peak and is joined by just malt support.  Some discernable alcohol, along with elements of papaya, sweet dried oranges and nectarines, and sugar-sprinkled grapefruit help to round out the flavor sequence.  Each first sip of each pour (about 4 oz. at a time) would hit like acupuncture on the tongue, but the sips at the end of each pour would be losing the initial liveliness of the carbonation.  Finishes with a slight hint of the bitterness displayed, transitioning into a honeydew aftertaste.  Overall, a solid IPA.

I had this about a week ago and Im sitting here wondering if this is the best IPA Ive ever had.  Im not sure what would top it.  I prefer Alpha King, but its not truly an IPA and I definitely prefer this to Stone, so maybe it is my favorite.  Just wonderful stuff-hoppy, complex, well balanced.  Wish I could drink it more often.  Badass...

Bottled.  Pours clear orange with a sizable ivory-colored head.  Oranges and grapefruit in the nose.  Big resiny, pine flavor.  Maltiness reminds me of walnuts and sunflower seeds.  Spicy for an IPA- but not in a bad way.  Great beer

Thin frothy head.  Off-white in color.  Succulent, juicy hops aroma.  Grapefruit, spruce, citrus, its all in there.  Makes my mouth water.  Color is a dark golden orange.  Wow, crisp and unbelievably easy drinking beer.  More hops with a some malts for backbone.  Great balance.  Plenty of spruce in there with a hint of butterscotch.  Finish is slightly dry with good lingering bitterness.  A great IPA.  Cant decide whether I like this or Stones Better.

Bottle.  Poured a beautiful amber color with a medium sized head.  This was my first IPA.  So now I know what hops are all about.  From the first drink to the last of this 22 oz. bottle my taste buds were just amazed.  I am eager to try other IPAs to see where this stands.  I have a Stone IPA in my fridge, think Ill try that one tomorrow.

Draft at San Diego Brewing Co.  Nice color with a decent head.  Lacing down the whole glass.  Aromas of hoppy citrus and coastal sage, some pine too.  Flavors were excellent.  Exactly what I have come to expect a great IPA to taste like.  Nice finish too.  Excellent IPA.

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2015 Pours with a medium-sized white head. Color is orange-amber. Aroma is hoppy, floral.  The first impression as it hits my tongue is that Ive been hit in the face with a sack of hops (not a bad thing as long as we remain figurative and not literal.)  Thin malt backbone. Not as much aftertaste as Stones great IPA.  Great hop burps, however.  Well done

UPDATED: AUG 24, 2005 Solid IPA.  Strong hops.  Smoother than Stones offering, but not quite as good.  Still, a very good IPA.  Kind of disappointed given AleSmiths pedigree.  But I will gladly drink this if Stone is unavailable.

Bottle. Full golden color with a thick and lasting white head. The aroma is very hoppy and very pleasant. The taste is a full sweet body dominated by the balanced and very bitter hoppy pattern. Very nice.
Nice mouth feel, well balanced hop. Smell of citrus. Nice smooth, too rare in Denmark

Courtesy of Pailhead. Pours copper color with no head, just a ring of film. Aroma very sweet caramel up front with big pine hop backing. Flavor starts the same caramel and fades into pine hops with a long aftertaste. very sticky hop residue. Great balance. Great lacing. Hard to outdo this.
murky pale amber with a white head and lace.  grapefruit aroma with a medium mouthfeel.  finish is a woodsy pine, earthy bitterness.

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2009 Medium orange-gold color with a fairly dense white head and a straight-up fresh hops aroma.  Lots of pineapple and citrus in the nose along with secondary resinous characteristics.  Great fresh hops flavors as well--more citrus, yellow fruits and resin--with refreshing bitterness and great crispness.  Well-balanced, dry body with only a slight acohol characteristic as the malt takes a backseat here; everything a good IPA should be.  Truly excellent.

Bottle: Dull golden, very cloudy, large white frothy head, lovely lacing.   Sweet nectar of a hop aroma.   Strong, yet smooth and somewhat of a subdued hop flavor at the start, midlly sweet, with a hint of long leave tobacco.   Big bodied, smooth mouthfeel, feels quite nice.   Finishes with a smooth bitterness, definitely not as assertive as a PNW example, yet it is full of hop flavor and goodness.   I am really pleased with this one.   Thanks Mark!
Bottle at tasting. Dark amber color with a small white head. Great complex aroma. Medium body with smooth texture. Good flavor with strong bitter finish.

Pours a really deep golden with a fluffy white head. Nose is heavy on pine with a malty backbone. Taste is very good, not quite stone, though. Pretty smooth and refreshing. I little overbittered perhaps, but still a nice and piney/sweet IPA. Top notch!

bomber pours a nice orange color with frothy white head.  aroma is great.  floral hops with some pineyness.  taste is excellent as well.  well balanced and not overdone.  while i didnt enjoy this as much as stone ipa, it is certainly one of the best out there.

22oz - Great floral hop nose that wont quit.  Smells fresh and sticky.  Copper color witha nice thick off-white head that slowly fades leaving plenty of lacing.  A burst of hop, citus, and a touch of carmel smack the tounge with each sip.  A very strong flavor that goes down incredibly smooth and slick.  Maybe the best IPA Ive had.

Poured from a bomber.  The aroma is of orange segments and pine.  Kinda reminds me of Bombay Sapphire gin.  Very strong.  Very delicious.  The appearance is also very nice.  VERY thick white head atop a slow but densely bubbling opaque copper body.  The lacing is nice.  The flavor is piney and malty, slight nuttiness to it too.  Light on the citrus in the flavor, reminds me more of a barleywine.  The palate is dry and bitter and has a very thick and creamy mouthfeel.

light orange color w/ a big frothy off white head that laces very well.  Smells incredible.. a little pine a lot of citrus hops, oranges and a very very light carmel malt.  Palate is big pretty creamy well coated.  Flavor is so very delicous.  Num Num lots of nice big balanced hop and malt.  Citrus hops a touch bitter and a great malt backbone a touch of oranges overall some damn good stuff like a fresh hoppy barleywine.. num num
Thanks to blake for this one.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2005 RE-RATE:  Aroma of grapefruit, lemongrass, coriander, and pine.  Appears clear golden orange-yellow with no effervescence, and with a thin creamy head that persists.  Flavor is pleasant bitter hoppy goodness, followed by pine and sweet malt.  Palate is thick and chewy.  Overall, not what I expected and definitely unique.

22 oz bottle. Popped this one in honor of my new great nephew (not sure hes actually born yet, but due any minute!). His father brought this to me from California. Thick creamy head. Almost no hops in the nose; all sweet malt.  Surprisingly wonderful flavor with ample hops in flavor and bitterness. Balances perfectly with the maltiness.  I crave hop flavor; this has a bunch but less than others, yet this is an excellent IPA due to the best balance experienced to date!

Bottle.  Medium amber in color.  Great long lived off-white head and fantastic lacing.  Aroma is very malty with a nice hoppy balance.  The aroma reminds me more of a barleywine than an IPA, very caramelly and sweet with a nice balance of pine resin.  Medium bodied, somewhat coats the tongue and palate.  Carbonation level is perfect.  First taste is malty, caramel flavored.  This fades into a nice slow hop bitterness that lasts for quite a while.  Never harsh or overpowering.  Probably the best IPA I have had to date.

UPDATED: JAN 12, 2006 Bottle:  Nice aroma of citrus and pine hops with some light caramel.  Pours a mostly transparent orange with a white head.  Very nice lacing.  Very well balanced.  Nice caramel malt presence up front.  Excellent citrus and pine finish.  Sliky smooth mouthfeel.  Absolutely loved this one.  The best IPA Ive had to date.
Floral hop nose with citrus hops in the taste. Creamy on the palate, bitter, gets somewhat sweet at the finish.

Bottle: Hazy gold in color with a spicy hop nose. Hints of pine and grapefruit reveal the cascade hops. Just the right malt presence (nutty & sweet) to balance the stong hops kick. Top notch; Ive been wanting to get the chance to try this for several years and it was worth the wait.

Floral hop aroma with lots of malt and slightly buttery element. Golden/orange color with lasting rocky off-white head. Floral/citric hops are main flavor component with good malt balance and slight daicetyl detectable. Creamy mouthfeel. Somewhat sticky finish with a lingering bitter/hoppy aftertaste. Excellent.

Very good IPA.  The balance between the malt sweetness and the hop bitterness is very well done, especially considering how much the pine and grapefruit hops struggle to dominate.  Looks good, too, golden amber body with a steady stream of bubbles beneath a rocky off-white head.  Great lacing/coating of the glass.  Nice lingering, dry bitter finish.  The alcohol doesnt make itself known until it starts to warm the body.

UPDATED: MAR 20, 2006 Pours a golden orange color. A bit hazy with a light white head.  Citrus hops (primarily grapefruit and citrus peal) mixed with fresh grain highlights from the malt make the  aroma most enjoyable and fresh.  The taste is very bitter.  Strong grapefruit is present throughout as is a citrus peal taste towards the end and during the after taste (which lingers long).  Carrying this along is some greenish grain (hay comes to mind).  The body is crisp and smooth.  Moderate carbonation.  Not too bad but not my favorite.  

Chalk this up to changing palet I suppose.  Retried at the 2nd anual ides of March beer tasting at my house (3-18-06).  Noted a color difference this time around that I described as hazy onion skin. No change score.  Aroma notes are surprisingly similar though I noted some grassyness and not grapefruit.  Still enjoyable but more balanced than I noted before.  The taste is what really changed for me.  Much more balanced than I noted before.  Malty chewy caramel with a citrus pine hop blend that was in no way over the top.  Great aftertaste of malty caramel sweetness (worth of 2 more taste points).  Creamy sticky mouth feel (impoves the palate rating one point). Overall, Im looking at a 4 here minimum.  Glad I took a chance on this one again.

Clear honey colored brew with an inch of white foam.Has a nice soft hoppy nose and an even milder malt nose.Taste isnt bad,kinda bitter but I am getting a mouthfull of grapefruit.Thias might be a little old.

Bottle poured a cloudy orange amber with a thick off white head and nice heavy lacing.
Aroma is heavy of citrus, grapefruit and hops.
Big citrus and mild hops flavor with a great easy bitter finish.
Very good, easy drinking IPA!
Caramel coloured, with a great off white head. Lots of hops, long powerfull bitter aftertaste. Smooth. A very nice IPA!
Golden with big offwhite head. The aroma is HOPS. Good smooth feel. Sweet and bitter with a long lasting bitterdry aftertaste..

pours golden amber with a creamy white head.  Piney hops aroma with some  citrus notes.  Spicy hops taste, this is interesting....in a very good way.  Citrusy up front with a bitter ending that lasts.  Good malt balance here.  I like this a lot.
The nose is simple hop heaven. The taste amazingly delievers on all that the nose promises. How do these guys do it?

Pours a very clear golden color despite the bottle conidtioning.  White head stayed in the glass until the drink was gone.  Very pleasant hop aroma.  Tastes smooth with the hops all over the place but still doesnt come off as overbearing.  I LIKE IT

Golden amber with orange accents.  Explosive cascade type aromatics, very fruity and resiny.  Medium heavy body with a slightly chewy palate, crisps up at the finish.  Resiny flavor in the nose, gives way to bitter fruitiness matched with a syrupy malt sweetness.  Alcohol warmth evident in the finish, counterpoint to a lasting bitter mouthcoat.  Excellent IPA, better than some hoity toity Imperial IPAs I have had.
best IPA I have ever had bar none! great head, nice lacing, wonderful hop aroma, easy drinking. cant wait to try another.

Well, bottle design must have kept the gents over at Alesmith up late one night working on this bottle.  However, it is one sweet smelling brew.  Some sweet fresh pine, star fruit, lemon, grapefruit.  Heavenly aroma, even my girlfriend thinks so.  THe flavor to this beast is odd.  It has a whole lotta bitterness up front, then a slicker sweet flavor. Decent malt flavor as well, subtle, but only noticable when the hops stop kicking my teeth in.

Alesmith continues to impress. This beer proves you dont have to "Imperialize" something to make it good. Pours a lightly hazy orange amber color with a thick and creamy off-white head. Thick patches of lacing in the glass. Big citrus and floral hops in the nose. Medium body with loads of hops, spice and citrus and a nice malt undercurrent. The finish is hoppy with noticeable pine and lingers well. Great work here.

Aroma was of a citrus variety. Pour from the bottle left little head and a dark amber body. At first it seemed the alcohol was the controlling flavor of this beer. At the finish those citrus hops gave this one a fruity flavor to the end. If you like high alcohol content hoppy beers youll most likely want to try this one.

Tap @ OBriens. Clear amber/copper w off white head that fell fairly quick, min lace. Aroma was potent hops & med roasted malt. Flavor was big, full bodied (pushing the double category). Had a nice sharp, tart, dry mouthfeel with a slight malt sweetness. Nice bitter hop bite. There was a slight cooked vegetables taste that faded as the beer warmed producing a pleasant spiciness and complexity I didnt notice at first. Alcohol is slightly noticable but well hidden for the amount.

UPDATED: MAY 25, 2005 Cloudy golden pour with a big white head that sticks around. Aroma is hoppy, pine and citrus. Taste is well balanced- hoppy, but with a definite sweet (malty) and sour (lemon) effect to make it more complex and unique. Fairly creamy mouthfeel. Definite presence of alcohol in the finish and aftertaste.

Aroma:  strong hop scents, some sawdust, and some sweetness

Appearance:  golden yellow, small white head, lacing

Flavor:  very sweet, very hoppy and dry, some woody flavors, some light fruits

Palate:  very dry, takes the skin off the tongue, interesting hoppy/light fruit aftertaste

Overall:  Still dont like IPAs, but if I did this would be a good one.

I must first point out thi sbeer has the best head I have yet seen. Large, fluffy, a bit rocky - it is quite nice with lots of staying power. Deep, midly hazy orange colour. nice piney hop aroma. Smooth and malty, with a nice transition to some bitter hops. leaves a nice aftertaste that sticks around for a bit. Even the bottle is cool!

Best IPA I have had so far.  Rich color and huge head that stays for the duration of the experience.  Sweet malty taste, hides any presence of alcohol.  Great hop aroma, and huge hop finish. California has perfected the pale ale.  Survived the flight home from San Diego to Rochester, too bad we cant get this on the East coast. Great beer.

A tiny bit hazy, golden orange/copper with a thick peaked off white head that leaes great lacing.  The aroma is very hoppy with most of the bitter aroma being very piney.  Very nice powerful hop flavor.  Bitter at the core; strong pine hpe flavor and a secondary floral hop sweetness followed by some distinct grapefruit. There is also a bit of underlying malt sweetness providing a creamy balance.  The lingering bitterness creates a nice bitter finish that begs for another sip.

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2005 Pours a nice coppery orange, with a billowy off white head.  Aroma is a good blend of cirtusy, piney hops and malt.  Aroma is more sweet malt and grapefruit hops.  Nice creamy mouth, and a good bitter bite.  A well balanced IPA.

(Bottle)Pours a dark amber with little head. Wow, wonderful citrus aroma. This beer is extremely well balanced. starts with hoppy flavors which then fades too a nice bitterness which is balanced nicely with a nice sweetness to counteract it. Nice velvety feel on palate. This is a great IPA which i hope to have again soon.

bottle thanks to squidget (i think?).  a glorious aroma of a breakfast of grapefruit with sugar poured on it.  some slight tanginess mixed, a beautiful bouquet for my nose. slightly more bitter in the flavor, but supremely balanced with a barely discernable fruit presence that perfectly blends in with the hops.  awesome beer, and my first from alesmith.  i hope theres more to come!

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2005  This is the best IPA I have ever had.  Pours a cloudy orange with a creamy head with great lacing.  The lacing is quite surprising considering it is not a Double IPA.  The the aroma has so much malt in it that you have to give it a 10.  There is also some citrus, graitfruit and a very sweet smell which I cant quite put my finger on.  The same smell is apparent in the Old Numbskull.  The taste is to die for in an IPA.  It has graitfruit, citrus and a lot of hops.  Plus some hard liquor which I am unfamilar with.  The sweetness is great with this brewery.  The Palate is far better then any IPA I have ever had.  I wasnt expecting this beer to be this spectacular.  I never knew that an IPA could be this great.  Im really glad I ordered this.  It was worth it.

Id like to sit down and drink this with an arrogant bastard...they seem very similar.  Tons of flavor, very dry, Shit load of hops...a side by side blind tasting would be a thousand times more fun than Pepsi vs Coke

UPDATED: JUN 13, 2005 GABF and from a bottle at my cousins house, 2004.  Damn solid IPA.  Creamier than I would expect in the mouthfeel, this still boasted a robust fruity hops that was crisp but not bitter.  All the wonders of the flavor (hops, melons) were present in the nose, as was a slight bready malt which came back to me on the finish.  Good beer.  Re-Rate: on cask at the Real Ale Festival, June 2005.  It was less impressive than I remembered.  I think this is definitely better out of the bottle.  Still very balanced, but everything was underwhelming.  Ive adjusted the overall down a couple points in consequence.

Bottle. Pours an orange copper/color. Nice sweet citric aroma. Hoppy and a little bit of spice. Huge hoppy/malty bitter flavor right up front. Some sweetness and pine as well. Alcohol is well masked. Very bitter finish.

This is one awesome IPA that is both very bold and in addition very balanced at the same time.  The hops jump out at you and are full of flavor.  This is a world class beer that i will have again and again.
COLOUR WAS RED TO ORANGE, VERY HOPPY, CITRUS AROMA WITH A BIT OF PINE, HAS A CLASSIC BITTER FINISH EXPECTED FROM AN I.P.A

Slightly cloudy Yellow color with large white head. Aroma is full on piney hops, olives, grapefruit, honey. Flavor is definitely hoppy, but pretty well balanced overall with a substantial malt character. A great general IPA.
Pour is hazy orangey amber with a nice fluffy off white head...smell is definately piney...taste is well balanced sweet malt then hops taking over...bitter hoppy finish...good IPA...

Sampled on tap, from my kegerator.  Very light copper/golden yellow in color with a creamy white head.  Sweet citrus fruits in the nose, accents of pine.  Starts assertively bitter in flavor, opens to a very well balanced sweetness and excellent citrus/piney hop flavor.  Finishes bitter and dry.  Mouthfeel is smooth, creamy, medium bodied with a dry citrus finish.  This is an excellent IPA that I enjoy often.
(Bottle)  Pours a lightly cloudy amber with a small off-white head.  Aroma of citrus and florals.  Bitter finish.  Hoppy flavor.

Thanks Santa!!  Aroma is sweet grapefruit and perfume.  Pours a hazy copper/orange body with a thick foamy white head that doesnt seem to be going anywhere anytime soon.  Great ipa taste.  Loads of hops very well balanced with a huge malt backbone.
Thx. Santa!  Cloudy gold with a craggy head.  Lemony, floral & herbal hops in the nose. Flavor is herbal, dusty malt.  Grapefruit.  I wish there was a bit more sweetness
hazy orange color with long lasting white lace.  Hoppity hop aroma.  Crisp, clean, solid IPA..

In my opinion, this is way overated.  dont get me wrong, its a great IPA, it has a nice aroma that promises hoppy goodness, and a flavor that delivers, but I feel that it lacks a bit.  it is a pretty straight forward for an IPA and doesnt really wow me like a beer with score over 4 should.  This is a great IPA that you should try, but it isnt as good as its said to be.

Cloudy golden color with a good sized white head that lasted until the end. Nice lacing on the glass, lots of yeast floaters. Great citrusy, hoppy aroma. Refreshing hop flavor with lots of grapefruit thrown in and just enough malt to almost balance it out. I wish this was more readily available, it could become my favorite everyday beer.
Very good.  Good strong hop nose with not much else.  Citrus in the taste, and I suppose a bit in the nose as well.  There si not much mult, for a regular IPA.  Thanks heemer77.

UPDATED: JAN 20, 2005 A large white head that was foamy and thick. Almost like eggwhites. The color is a very deep gold and it is highly carbonated. The aroma reminds of the best IIPAs. Citrus, bread, pineapple, pine and bread crust. The taste has a strong orange peel and pine character. Notes of salt and bread. The finish is peppery with a weird orange pulp. The mouthfeel is medium with plenty of carbonation. I would like a little more body and malt. Overall, still an excellent beer. Recieved in a trade with flipbrewer.
Amber orange ale with a huge off-white head. Wonderful hops in aroma with citrus notes. Citrus and hops with a good malt backbone. Very well balanced and pleasant.
Thanks, EDA.  Cloudy, yellowish brown with a nice white head. Nice hoppy aroma and nice hoppy flavor. Nice malty character. Well made beer. Enjoyable. Drinkable.
Shared bottle provided by Eyedrinkale (thanks!). Poured a medium, cloudy amber color with a white head. Fruity and citric aromas and tastes. Nicely bitter. Very solid IPA.
Thanks to EDA...Cloudy unattractive yellowish brown. White head. Nice hoppy aroma and flavor. This has some good malt backbone, and wonderfully well made. These guys know their stuff.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text: Bottle. Orange color, hazy from the brewers yeast in the bottle, white head that left lacing all over my glass. Floral, malty, and hoppy aroma, very pleasant. Sweet malt flavor, gentle citrus overtones, generous hops, and extremely smooth. Hops dominate the aftertaste. Tried it side by side with the Stone IPA, I thought it was much smoother with a creamy head due to the bottle conditioning. Otherwise both are exceptional, this is a fantastic IPA.

Cloudy orangish yellow color, big head, short lasting creamy hop aroma, crisp sharp distinct hop citrus taste, not much malt to speak of, flavor stayed full the entire bottle, a wonderful IPA but not available in the midwest and its not so much better than others to include shipping on the price

22oz brown bomber with a plain silk screen lettering of Alesmith IPA nothing fancy. This one pours a hazy darker orange color with an off white head. Descent retention and lacing as I drank this. Very hoppy aroma with notes of citrus and pine coming through but not overly hoppy. This one is surprisingly balanced considering the hopped up nose on it. Flavor starts with a citrus hoppiness with some piney notes and finishes with the hop bitterness. It has a definite spicy kick to it with a slight sweet malt in there as well. Very nice flavor to it, complex and lots to sort out. This has about a medium body with good carbonation and a creamy smooth mouthfeel. This one was a joy to drink too bad this stuff isnt regularly available around this parts or I would drink it all the time. Another great from Alesmith.

golden amber color, tannish rocky long lasting head w/ lots of lacing.  floral hop, pine, and citrus aroma.  flavor is all hop, very bitter.  grapefruit peel flavor too.  resiny mouthfeel and aftertaste.  sparce but sparkly carbonation.

UPDATED: NOV 27, 2004 Pours a bright orange with small white head. Aroma of flowers and citrus. Flavor is very full and balanced. The hops are very expressive, and the malt balances out the palate. A great beer! Thanks to IMTheOptimater for this very tasty brew!
Cloudy orange/amber coloured. Very nice aromas with loads of citrusy cascade hops. Very hoppy and bitter flavour. Really good.

not significantly superior to many other good American IPAs I have had. Full mouthfeel with citrus and dough. Somewhat overcarbonated that with bitterness and pine and tad grassiness, set off my mouth. Good accompanyment to dinner

UPDATED: SEP 17, 2005 Bottle. Strong hop smell. Beautiful pour and head. Hazy yellow color. Bitter taste. Strong citrus flavor. Proto-typical American Hophead IPA. Im not an IPA fan, but this is one of the best Ive had.

Pours cloudy dark orange with a frothy white head. ..5 min later and the bubbles are still rising. Citrus aroma and the taste to match. The pine taste must account for the resiny aftertaste which is strong at times although this beer pulls it off well. The warmth on the way down would signal the extra dose of alchohol. A very good IPA overall, although not quite as good as Stone.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2005 22 oz bomber. Im not sure how old this bottle is but its already started to grow floaties and lot of sediment in the beer. It still keeps a very floral hop and citrus aroma that is fresh and lively. The flavor is extremely bitter and prime example of the style. Love this IPA and is probably top 10.

220z. bomber:  This lovely brew pours a hazy, darker golden color.  Some head to it.  The aroma is hops, and all hops, but not overpowering.  Piney, citrus, floral and grassy.  The taste is quite good.  The taste is quite hoppy, but only somewhat bitter.  The tastes are very well balanced.  Some fruits in the aftertaste and the hopiness lingers nicely in your mouth.  An excellent brew.

Poured a great golden color, Nice head. first taste, Hops,Hops,Hops! Very nice, warming ale. Nice flavor, Ive been aging this one only for a few months, but tonight it looked at me and said, "Drink me" Im glad I did, beautiful beer! Ill have many more!

Poured a murky amber color with an offwhite head which left a lacing on the glass.  Aroma is typical for a good IPA; strong and hoppy.  Taste has a strong hops presence with a subtle hint of malt.  Very, very similar to Stone IPA.  Not quite as drinkable as Hop Devil, but an excellent IPA.

Sampled from draught at AleSmith Brewing Company.Hazy orange golden body, fine white head. Hops is dominating in the aroma that has a nice sweet fruity middle. Very flavorfull and mostly bitter hoppy taste. Fruity, orangy and grassy notes. Very smooth and extremely complex. An excellent IPA that I was very happy to get to taste from draught!

i dumped this one into my rouge pint glass.a nice 1 inch thick head foamed up then thinned down a bit.again nice little bubbles floating up.the taste....excellent.hoppy but not in an obnoxious way,and still very smooth as all the alesmith brews are.

Pours a mix between burgundy and orange with a glimpse of purple. The lace is extreme. The bubbles are small. The retention is glorious. 

Grapes, cranberries pine cones, grapefruits, peaches and lemon in the nose.

Pleasantly flavorful. Peaches, grapefruit and lemons. This is hop juice. Great IPA.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2006 Bottle. Thick and well carbonated. Dense white head. Light caramel color with a red hue. Smells of caramel, grass, citrus with a slight sour aroma. Good lacing. Starts tart, resiny and slightly sweet. Has a good body but could use a little more malt flavor to back it up. Finishes bitter and moderately dry. Very well balanced.

Thanks to Lord Gorlock for sharing his Alesmith!
This is a good IPA that is balanced slightly toward the bitter side as far as balance goes, but I must wonder "why brew this beer?"
Yulesmith is a big IPA, the regular IPA is too. Why compete against yourself?? The ESB is a work of art also, this IPA just covers ground already well covered in my opinion. Just brew Yulesmith year round.

UPDATED: JUL 21, 2005 (Thanks go out to Stephen the DarkElf for this one!)  Orangey color with a whispy, bubbling (read: LOUD) head.  Aromas were on the piney side, with a little bit of malt in the mix.  Soft maltiness backing oily hops with a little resiny quality to them.  Balanced beer.  Citrusy finish that turns bitter as it closes out.  I wasnt overly impressed, here, but I could have simply waited too long to drink my bottle.  Ill have to get to the brewery the next time Im in San Diego and try this fresh.

ReRate, 7/19/05  Massive blast of orangey, lemony hops on your sniffer.  Awesome body/mouthfeel.  Great balance between the oily (but not sticky) hoppiness and the complex malt profile.  Jammin IPA.
deep golden hue w/an small off white head.  strong citrusy/hoppy w/some hints of fruits in the aroma.  very well balanced taste, citrusy too, bitter dry end.
An unclear orange beer with a small disappearing beige head. The aroma is great of hops, oil, and grass. The flavor is sweet and very hoppy, but also with notes of oil and grass. A lovely IPA.

Orange amber with a fine haze of carbonation blossoming into an eighth inch of creamy white head. Nose is hoppy, very earthy, with a note of pine and hint of musty wood. Medium bodied and not the least bit sticky, aggressive carbonation leads to a decrease in perceived thickness; it can almost come across as watery at times. A little burn here and there from the alcohol at only 7.25% detracts a bit from the presentation. Definitely a hop monster but the hops lean to an earhy pine bitterness rather than the vibrant citric or floral aroma I prefer. Slightly lacking in malt depth. Much better as it warms. At 55 degrees F, I would have given this around a 3.2.
A great IPA! Poured an orange color, with a light creamy head and aroma was hoppy and fruity. Flavor was hoppy, but very well balanced. This beer is awesome!

Cloudy amber-orange, bottle-conditionned, smallish off-white head. Piney christmas tree aroma feels very green. Big coniferous seeds in the forms of C-hops make the malt appear very subdued. Taste is fresh and rather complex for the style. Orange skin, earth, and piney bitterness. Finish is long, hoppy, very dry, green, but perhaps a bit too alcoholic for its relatively low strenght. Hoppy all the way through, no mistakes about it.  Medium to full body, moderate fitting carbonation. Id just have loved to see more of the alesmiths fabulous malt manipulations.

Nice cloudy amber color with sediment in suspension. Resinous aroma of piney hops with caramel. Balanced flavor of piney and green hops with caramel. Bitter finish. Light to medium body, creamy texture. Very good and enjoyable.

Citrus (grapefruit/orange) and pine, herbal, spicy, fruity hop nose Orange-brown coloured body with plenty of yeast in suspension. Small, dense white head recedes to cover. Earhty, vegetal hoppiness with sweet malt flavour. Alcohol very apparent in the dry finish. Comfortable in the mouth. Easy drinking. Bottle enjoyed with beerbuzzmontreal, lubiere, MartinT and Rastacouere.

Pours a hazy orangey color with small suspended particals that give it an apricot preserve/orange marmalade kind of look.
head was large and fluffy with a beige tint. chunky lacing.
Initial aroma was piney, with some lemony character, and some sweetness in the background.
Flavor was bitter/sweet  ruby red grapefuit with a little sugar on top.
finish was medium length and mildly bitter.
Not as good as Stone IPA but still very good.

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2005 draft at stones 8th ann:  nose of citrus snappy hops. fresh grass and dopamine.  down the hatch gets some of the same hoppy like features the nose carries.  some bitterness to the end of the crack from the hop in the grapefruit genre.  a solid ipa....  had this last night again without being snookered at a beer festival and it was faaaantastic!!! right in the same class as my faves....stone and bear republic. this is a must have on hand whenever you feel like a REAL IPA!!

Draft. Amber color. Big white head. Grapefruit aroma. Some malt backing in the flavor - just enough to mellow out the grapefruit bitterness that comes with a hint of pine resin. Not over the top at all. Well done

Floral citrus hop aroma - plentiful nonstop nose-festival.  I could drink this one all day long.  Medium bodied sweet malts paired with a sharp citrus grapefruit warming hop with a minty floral herb ending.  Thanks to Sean DrunkAsASkunk for leaving this with me.  I was going to share it with Rockinout, but it accidently got opened up at my daughters birthday party.  Excellent stuff - Ill have to set up a trade to get more!

UPDATED: APR 26, 2005 Got this in a trade with DarkElf. Certainly up there as one of the best IPA Ive ever had. Pours a medium light copper with an off white head. Aroma is pure HOPS, very floral. Taste is deliciously hoppy with tons of grapefruit/citrus, vanilla, pine and great malt backing. Perfect sweetness and nice bitter aftertaste. Mouthfeel is very full, round and creamy. The flavors just dance all over your tongue. Great lacing and head retention. IPAs just dont get any better than this! I just may move to San Diego for this brew.
a very strong bitter IPA.  Ill give them credit for building a very solid IPA with great IPA characteristics, but i thought it was too much for the stoutie that i am  - see my speedway rating  :)

Aroma of sweaty feet (I guess hops are supposed to smell that way) , mellows when I think about to a sprucey foresty smell. Dark copper appearance, thick frothy mocha head. Good thick mouthfeel, creamy actually. Flavor has the usual citrus accents, done well, not overblown or tongue numbing. All around a decent IPA.

Toffee, grapefruit aroma.  Dont drink the foam -- its just like grapefruit juice.  Grapefruity, buttery at times, sweet when you can get past the hops.  Piney.  Technically good, but its not going to be a fave.

Another huge thank you to DrunkAsASkunk.  If this keeps up, Im going to build a shrine to Sean in my basement.  Poured turbid dark straw with a huge, frothy white head and lacing.  Aroma of hops, fruit, florals, malt, citrus, and pine.  Tasted hoppy, fruity, floral, with hints of grapefruit, pine needles, honeydew melon, and citrus.  Finishes hoppy, fruity, slightly dry with a firm, dense, velvety finish.  The head and lace lingered and lingered, producing creamy white globules that would make Ron Jeremy jealous.  As it warmed, I noticed caramel, honey, and a flavor reminiscent of DFHs Albert the Enamel Animal.  This one is world class!

very hoppy almost imperial like ipa.  taste is bitter, piney and grapefruity.  pours out a dark orange color with a thick white head.  there is alot of shit floating in the beer towards the end.  has a nice hoppy nose with a little bit of sweetness to it.  this is a damn nice ipa, one of the finer ones ive sampled.

Very very hoppy IPA. Alesmith rated best, when youve consumed their beers you know why. Gigantic white head out of bottle.  Citrus particulates swimming through this beer. Sweet, Hoppy, nice malt.  A little Salty. Head lingers forever.  Thin, wheat style color to this IPA. Very very good as I said.  This is a beer to be savored and enjoyed. Alesmith is 2 for 2 with me. I cant imagine anything they sell be disappointing.

Cloudy orange with a dense white head. Aroma of pineapple, grapefruit and pine. Very bitter punch-you-in-the-mouth taste up front. Lingering grapefuit flavor in the aftertaste. Not much malt flavor or sweetness come through.

Not only one of the best IPAs Ive ever had its one of the best beers.  Every aspect brings a smile to my face.  The pour is great, the hazy orange color with a pillowy beige head that stays.  The piney citrusy hop aroma is lovely.  The taste?  Nothing short of terrific.  Very balanced, hoppy, hoppy, and hops again.  Theres just enough maltiness to keep it all in check.  Ive got to get more of this.

If IPA were art, this would be Michaelangelos David.  Brewery fresh in a growler, this wonder pours a clear golden-straw and produces a billowy white head.  Bubbles ascend in a spiral, nuggets of sparkling gold in a sunrise-yellow background.  The aroma is pungent and gripping, citrus, pine, purfume, a touch of apricot and flowers.  The bitterness is bracing but gentle- steel wrapped in silk.  Begins like eating a grapefruit, and mellows into softer citrus, peaches, plums and cherries toward the finish.  Malt is well balanced, but mainly for the background.  Crisp mouthfeel, lively carbontion, and a dry finish wrap it up and leave you wanting more.  This IS the best IPA Ive ever had.

Suprisenly I havent rated this one yet, so a pint at Papago was in order.  Light straw colored yellow, with a  small fluffy head.  Nice bold citrus aroma. Smooth hoppy mouthfeel.  Malts are there but just for the sweetness.  Somewhat warming and mellow  that continue through to the aftertaste.  A great refreshing beer.
Deep golden color with a full off-white head.  Purfumy floral nose.  Soft on the palate.  Strong malt sweetness with a floral hop bitterness.  Very nice balance for a West Coast IPA.

Alesmith tap room.  Hazy orange body, fluffy white head.  Awesome nose of fresh sticky sweet pine, spruce,  caramel, white grapefruit,  and all things juicy citrus.  Flavor is greatly bittered, but with a nice sweet malty backbone to put up a fight for a shot at balance.  Hops win out by a hair.  Medium to full-bodied,  soft carbonation, bitter creamy finish.  For just an IPA, this one deserves your hophead attention immediately....
Amber with white head.  Cascade hops dominate the nose.  Grapefruit.  Appealing.  Body was creamy and smooth.  Juicy flavor with just the right bitterness.  Refreshing and clean and crisp.
22 oz bottle:  yo, this brew is so tasty.  mmm, pours a deep golden color, with slight cloudation...  such a large fluffy (looser) head.  smells like roasty hops. smooth butter.  this beer is great.

As advertised strong hop aroma. Nice starting head finishes a bit clumpy. Sticky lacing. Enough malt to hold the hops. Smooth enough up front with long citrus and wood finish. Bitter but still refreshing. Does not dry out the mouth. Strong hops without noticeable hop oil.

Nice orange slightly hazed body. The head is gorgeous, fine particled and light tan. Yum looks very appealing. The aroma is a big kick of grapefruit and pine. The flavor is loads of hops, citurs and pine with enough malt to see things through and keep the relatively high alcohol content totally hidden. Medium body that is quite luxurious. A really fine IPA.

(22oz bottle) Huge, fluffy, white head with an orange, cloudy body. Nose of an orange field in late summer. No carbonation. Sweet, tart, tangy and with a Hi-C hoppiness that only a West Coast brewer can do right. Very good. Many thanks to Lubiere for sharing this with me...
An excellent IPA. Poured a hazy golden amber, decent head. Strong, rich hop aroma with hints of citrus. Nicely balanced flavor: hoppy with some sweet malts. Very good.

22 oz bottle, courtesy of Hi Time Wine.  Hazy, cloudy scintillating orange, with a smallish but quite stable creamy head.  Massive aroma of fresh spruce needles, apricots and grapefruit, both pungent and fresh; rapturous.  Mouthpuckering initially, a powerful citrusy bitterness carries through all the way to the end, juicy and fruity, tart and strongly carbonated; quite full-bodied, perhaps a bit much to be refreshing -- this is a sipping IPA, despite the 22 ounces.  Doesnt displace Stone at the top of my IPA list, as its just a bit too funky and heavy for me, but memorable and wonderful in its own right.

Poured a hazy copper, orange color with a small sticky off white head that diminished to a small film but still left nice lacing.  Amazing citrus and pine hop aroma.  Sweet malts, bitter hops, perfect mouthfeel, perfect balance.  It doesn't taste bitter enough to be an Imperial, but the balance is superb... YUM!  Thanks Marc

Nice tan head, look like fresh powder on the slopes.  Nice amber coloration.  Im not a hophead, but I am getting closer, and this is hop heaven...  I dont think its as good as Ruination, because Ruination blew me away, but this is a very solid beer.  Nice IPA, very smooth, balanced, complex.  Very nice vanilla undertones in the background which help make this beer what it is.
I love IPAs.  I love Alesmith.  They do one of the best.  Hops, Hops, Hops!  Great flavor and a great beer.

A solid IPA. Pours a nice amber color with a lacing white head around the glass. Floral hops spring from the aroma. Nice taste. Smooth, kind of creamy. Hoppy. Great balance. Probably rivals the other IPA made in San Diego! Bought this 22oz bottle from Beverages and More in San Diego.
UPDATED: JAN 2, 2005 It pours great.  It drinks better.  Lots of hops.  Nothing else really stuck out but damn this is a solid soild beer. Daddy likes.
This was a really great IPA.  Poured a cloudy orange color with a small white head.  The taste was very balanced and complex.  Highly recommended.

Bottle.  Pours a beautiful orangey amber color with a huge creamy white head that lingers and leaves great lacing.  Aroma is heavenly, a caramel maltiness that's just discernable under the brash and dominant grapefruit and pine hops.  Flavor is delicious, sweet and rich initially with an amazingly tart and pleasingly bitter character that rears up and then mellows into a dry, puckery finish.  Exceptional IPA, almost bordering on being an Imperial - another fine product from Alesmith.  How lucky am I to have them in my hometown?!

Near amber color with a tall fluffy light tan head. Caramel coated hops (pine and grapefruit) aroma. Smooth, near oily, feel Orange and grapefruit hops abound. Malt sweetness to keep them in check. A touch acidic for me in the finish.
Thanks to SDBruboy for this one. Nice solid west coast IPA. Nothing really stood out besdies the west coast hops. Very drinkable and very good.

Lovely bright reddish hue, a full, opaque orangish color, with a good, whitish head.
Aroma: lively hop component, fresh, alert and awake, buzzing with grapefruity notes, full with fruit.
Taste: mmm, buzzing with nicely fruity hops, a constant hoppy delivery on the palate, yum, yum, yum, sharp, bright, delicious, juicy...did I say "yum"??
Nicely lingering finish, fully flavored, unstoppably delcious...seriously, this is one IPA you can sit down and get familiar with. 
A very solid IPA, one I've got to rank among the best!
Thanks to gusler for bringing it to me!

UPDATED: APR 11, 2004 Yum that smell is one of the best malt and citrus and bit of pine.  Orange tint well carbonated leaving a fairly big head. The flavor starts with a hop bang, malt comes through just in time to have its read end kicked by more hops, a strong bitter finish. Hop monsters hop monster.

The beer was shipped to me in a handsome bomber by eyedrinkale.  When poured into my usual pint glass, it had an orange amber colored body with a 2-inch thick beige head and a lively natural carbonation.  Head retention was excellent and there was a ton of lace left all around as the beer went down.  Aroma was assertive with floral hops dominating the bouquet.  The taste was a bit brash with a strong alcohol presence, which was not quite hidden under the hops as it should be.  There were notes of citrus on the palette, but these were quite subdued.  The hop bitterness was also relatively low; however they added a good deal of spicy character to the mix.  The mouthfeel was appropriately dry and creamy for the style.  Alcohol burn detracts a bit from drinkability.  A nice solid IPA to be had here.

Pours a deep cloudy amber colour with a frothy white head and sheets of lacing and lots of floaties. Nose is citrus and floral hops with some maltiness. Flavour is citrus and pine with a malt underpinning it all. Finish is fruity and dry.

Golden cloudy with a thin white head that is medium lasting. good lacing. lots of grapefruit hops with some pollen. The taste is very grapefruit hops. Very straight foreward and assertive but not offensive. The body is average and tingly.

Excellent IPA, orange tint to the copper/amber color, nice thick white head that laced around the glass, nose was full of hops, strong hoppy flavor with citrus tones, the oils & resin from the hops covered the mouth, nicely balanced with a great malty character, dry & spicy finish, very smooth & drinkable, medium-full body, awesome IPA

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2015 Deep orange, with a pretty but rapidly fading head.  Hoppy aroma is of low key grapefruit, followed by an aggressive earthy note, some pine, and a slight nutty note.  Hops and malts are nicely balanced here.  Definite roasty character, mingles pleasantly with earth and pine hops.  A bit resinous, but not sticky.  The alcohol also makes itself evident in the flavor profile.  A well done and interesting IPA, reminds me quite a bit of DFH 90 minute.  Thanks Eyedrinkale!  RERATE:  11 years later.  Feeling old.  Happy they are in RVA now.  No change, although I would drop the "roasty note" comment.  Still a classic IPA.

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2004 Strong malts and hop flavor. nice brown body in color that makes this rich yet not overdone beer is a gem. To bad not sold in houston Finish is smooth with no aftertaste. Very complex gets even better as it warms body clings to the glass until the last drop. A must try for "hop heads"
might have been the glassware but had a dirty dishwater smell.  extremely hoppy, floral taste. a great knockout punch of flavor. nice amber color. this is my favorite ipa to date.  good stuff indeed.
2004 SE gathering. Strong hop presence in the aroma and flavor. Golden brown color with rather high carbonation. Very enjoyable.

A decent IPA, not my favorites but a very good outing.  Golden-amber body, with some nice citrusy grapefruit aroma.  Too heavy on the cascade though.  Very sweet, and not enough malt to balance out the over hopped taste.  Slightly astringent and piney, but good, easy to drink, just glad I got to try it.

Sample glass, RateBeer Southeastern Gathering.  Cookie malt is balanced nicely with piney, citric hops.  Orange-amber body is slightly hazy.  Very sweet and bitter overall.  Nice balancing acidity.  Medium body, creamy texture, lively carbonation.  The bottom line is: an pleasant (and unusual) sweetness in this IPA is thinned out a little to much by the carbonation.

UPDATED: FEB 24, 2004 Copper, with a nice sturdy head. Earthy, bourbon and caramel aroma. Resiny hops dominate, and there is a nice play between bitter and subtle sweet flavors. Woodsy flavor, and also some toffee flavors through to the finish. Powerfully hoppy, but also brewed with finesse. Nice. Sampled at 2004 Southeastern Ratebeer Gathering, Atlanta.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2004 Rerate thanks to DavidP and cquiroga... no more stingy numbers! Hazy gold color, soapy white head. Very nice hoppy aroma... grapefruit, grapefruit rind, orange, and a flowery pine touch. Also has a definte caramelly malt presense. Very pleasant and perky aroma. Same with the flavor. Citrus, sweet caramel, etc. Not overpowering in any way.... right amount of bitter citrus, right amount of dry rind, right amount of sweetness. Smooth palate. Like a normal IPA, except delicious :)
UPDATED: JUN 22, 2004 This one is a nice IPA. Dark orange appearance. Falvor is very hoppy with citrus, pine, oranges. This is a must try for anyone who likes IPAs. Heavens Yes!
Poured cloudy orange/tan with a thick white head. Hoppy aroma and a pleasant hoppy, candy flavor. Reminds me of an Arrogant Bastard, if maybe toned down a bit. Very good.
This is a great IPA. Big hop and citrus aroma, with a nice hop bite and enough sweetness to mellow it at the swallow. I couldn't detect the ABV, it was a zesty and refreshing beer.

Dark copper/amber color with a creamy-like head and a ring of lacing. This was a pretty bottle conditioned bottle surprisingly. The aroma is hoppy with citrus with a bit of crisp base malts. The flavor is very dry and astringant with a sweet/bitter balance that is nice but it seems too dry to be real balanced. This was tasty for sure, but just wasn't as good as it was lived up to be. Glad I got to try it though.

Light copper pour with an egg white head and pretty good lacing.  Big citrus hops come out first in the nose, with a touch of floral hops. A bit o the pine is apparent.  Comparitive to the nose, the flavors are a pretty well blended mix of malts and hops, both floral and citrus. Some lighter citrus fruits are evident. Medium bodied, a nice, mellow palate, and just a hint of bitter hops finish this off. Great IPA.

750mL bottle. This is a fantastic IPA! Hazy amber colour, little to no head, some lacing. Citrusy hop aroma is tantalizing. Huge hop flavour, wonderfully balanced. I wish I had more of this stuff, I absolutely love it.

Murky amber in colour with a thin off white coloured head.  Aroma was nicely hopped, with lots of grapefruit, citrus and pine.  Flavour was hoppy, citrusy (grapefruit, lemons), almost peppery.  Finished with a moderate hoppiness, medium lingering bitterness.  Thanks Eyedrinkale.

Mildly cloudy amber nectar with an off-white head that slowly diminished to a thin layer. Fruit explodes out of the bottle let alone the glass - grapefruit and oranges and bananas (?) and of the course the expected hoppiness doesn't disappoint. Very smooth with a surprisingly (and almost disappointingly) mild bitter finish. Very nice - and nice of radiomgb to contribute this one to our little football fest.

I can't think of anything negative to say about this IPA. It is a pure, outstanding example of the style.

Pours a cloudy amber with a huge head that leaves a very nice lace down the glass.

Scent is strong with floral hops with a hint of malt.

Taste is well balanced considering all the hops. Cascade grapefruit takes center stage. Not the most complex IPA, but damn good.

Mouthfeel is creamy with a bit of a bite. Overall this is very nice and definately worth seeking out.


Thanks to EyeDrinkAle for the bottle.
Light amber/orange color with a white head. Resinous hop aroma. Flavor of malt and hops. Seems nicely balanced to me.

Lightish amber, full foamy head.  Resiny and floral aroma, bare hint of citrus.  Thickish resiny mouthfeel, with tingly resin flavors.  Pine flavors linger above a strongly bitter, somewhat ashy and dry finish.  As with their Extra Pale Ale, this beer hides the malt, although what is there is clean and sweet, with a roundish front - but the hop resins dominate quickly and coat the tongue.  This is perhaps a good candidate for cellaring.

Nice thick head.  Solid, big but tempered nose and a ton of citrus and pine in the mouth supported by sweetness.  A bit more herbal than most big IPAs, but it's a balanced 'herbal'.  I also like how the wood flavors are worked in, but do not compromise the sweetness.  Great malt balanced.  Great body--no syrup at all. First rate.
