Real Good IPA.  Dark bronze under a light creamy off white head that left a good lace as it settled.  Aroma, much like the X, is powerfull and full of different hops.  This IPA just has bit more malt in the nose.  Slightly spicey evergreen flavors balanced quite well with some sweet malt flavors.  Slightyly oily palate with a great lasting finish.  Wish it was easy to come by on the east but, I think I can live with Hop Devil.
All the aroma I thought it would be. Cleart amber color with thick sustainable head. Very rich malty body, restrained and complex. Incredibly well balanced with a slightly bitter aftertaste.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2004 1/16/04.  Poured out of 22 oz. bottle, bought at Liquorama in Upland, CA 12/10/03.  Dark amber golden, clear body.  Very attractive and full appearance.  Chunky lacing on modest, beige head that dissipates.  Lovely, strong, full aroma of honey malts with rounded hop depth.  Syrupy.  Taste is straight chewy hops and resin, with a subtly sweet outline (yes, it is a bit like corn) and a hint of caramel malt.  Tiny bit of citrus and some pine that mostly shows up in the peppery finish.  Somewhat drying in the mouth.  Very full body for an IPA with nice, creamy texture and just enough hop bite.  Finish opens up very long and very strong, like it keeps unfolding in your mouth to new levels of complexity.  Fantastically bold for an IPA and very drinkable.  Just a terrific beer.

UPDATED: MAR 16, 2004 Re-Rate: No aroma or taste a poor example of an IPA let alone a West Coast IPA.  How this ranks above a 2.5 is beyond me.

Well this is a major disappointment.  Upon first opening a corn aroma.  Slightly hazy bronze color.  The taste does not get any better or does anything tho confirm the aroma is wrong, weak body and corn taste.  A very poor example of an IPA as I can not figure out what the are trying to accomplish with this other than a poor East coast IPA or an skunked English IPA.

UPDATED: FEB 29, 2004 Foamy tan head over a pretty red-copper body.  Clear, no floaties.  Delightlful spicy-sweet aroma.  Nutmeg, coriander and alcohol?  Bittering hops too, of course.  The balanced flavors and smooth mouthfeel really come together well on this beer.  Your tongue salivates when first meeting the beer, the start has citrus tartness and caramel sweetness (credit to Indra for that bit).  The finish is piney with a touch of pepper.  My only detraction is a heavy plum taste present throughout - it serves to bring down the bright hoppy flavors.  A fantastic IPA!  They're not trying to knock you on your ass with hops here, they've made a balanced hoppy brew.  Too often IPAs are just a pale with extra hops thrown in, the brewer put no effort into making a thoughtful beer with with well-rounded flavors.

First of all this was one of the coolest brewers I've ever met. He spent about an hour with us out of towners (me and my fiancee) and we sampled everything he offered us and bought a whole bunch to. This pours a deep unfiltered amber and it's head is a masterpiece in and of itself, dense and creamy. It has the best aroma of any beer ever.(PERIOD) The initial shock is that with all the hop, grapefruity, piney aromas, this beer is not excessively bitter. Now don't get me wrong, this IPA would still get a fizzy-yellow-bland beer drinker to shit a brick but when compared with other fine IPAs, this is tame in bitterness,...and bitterness alone. Man is there some amazing hop flavors buried in this beer. For all you homebrewers out there, he said that he used the equivelant of 8 oz. of dry hops per 5 gallons. WOW! Hopheads rejoice and find a new form of hopheaven in the flavor and aroma of this finely crafted ale.

The commericial description is highly accurate, so let me just take this opportunity to just praise the beer for being incredibly flavorful and a just plain great IPA.  Yum.  Yum.  Yum.  Grapefruit and hops, mild malts and full, round body here.  I intend to drink a lot of this.

Woo doggie, this is one awesome IPA - Floral hops and sweet candy in the aroma - golden with a slight copper tint, decent lacework - BAM, extreme yet balanced attack of hops and malty sweetness on the palate - apricots, citrus (grapefruit) - tingly carbonation - some pine in the mix - a world-class IPA.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2011 ReRate # 2-im really bringing this one down.  this beer could be the most over-rated beer i have had in a long time.  since my last rating, my palate has become much more sensitive to off flavors and body.  this beer has a very catty nose, almost like smelling cat piss in a hot old house.  Flavors are catty as well with lots of tropical notes but has a green apple type flavor as well.  seems like the beer is not very well put together.  wow how my palate has changed.  the palate is terribly astringent with a palate ripping carbonation.  maybe this beer is old?  i dropped my score down almost a whole point!   
ReRate-im going to bump up the score on this one.  I got to sample a bomber for myself last night and it was a wonderful experience.  all the stuff below is correct.  What i didnt emphasize was the balance of this brew.  the aroma is wonderful as well.  Alesmith knows how to make IPAs thats for shure!
22 oz bomber-sampled with whaleman-pours a medium apricot/orange huge.  small off white head.  medium carbonation.  Weak aroma for a west coast ipa, but reminded us of dreadnaught jr.  citrus and pine through the palate, but in the finish, the pine wins.  decent malt for this style  hops are not as strong as i was expecting, especially for a left coast ipa.

UPDATED: JUL 17, 2005 Bright apricot body with a slight haze caused by thousands of micro floaters. Head is tight, foamy, and slightly off-white. Smell initially reminded me of a junior Dreadnaught. Aroma notes include prominent grapefruit, yeasty musk, and something distinctly savory and nutty akin to peanuts. The nuttiness comes out in the flavor as well and reminds me of really good cashew butter. I think this property is coming from the hops. Or maybe I just had a stroke and the olfaction and taste centers in my brain have been fried by too much good beer on this fine day.

The aroma of this beer is truly great, very floral and hoppy with a mild hint of citrus.  Large head with good lacing and strong carbonation.  Flavor is smooth and well balanced but a little mild for my taste in IPA's.  Slightly bitter after taste, but pleasing to the palate nonetheless.

aroma is of pine needles and citrus. pours deep golden with a huge off white head that dissipates into a creamy normal sized head. flavor is very hoppy with pine and citrus dominating the flavors. there is also a very good malt balance to this beer.  an excelent ipa. thanks to brodie for this one.

Fruity, green, flowery aroma, just slightly spicy and malty, with hints of wax, pine, grapefruit, tangerine and light honey, also some tinges of alcohol.  Medium copper color with an exceedingly fine, lasting, creamy head and seemingly pointillist-conceived lacing.  Juicy and hoppy up front, notes of lemon, grapefruit, toasty, light caramel malt and flowery sweetness before the spicy, peppery, dry, nicely bittering finish.  Somewhat chewy mouthfeel, medium-full bodied with a complimentary mild effervescence on the palate.  Some mild warmth in the gullet from this one.  Nicely done.  Cheers, Chris.
Tap @ Bistro 6th Annual IPA Festival (August 9, 2003).  Medium golden color with an off-white head.  Nice cascade aroma and smooth hop, grass, pine, and floral flavors.

22 oz. Bottle.  This beer poured with a really impressive, rocky head.  I've never seen anything like it.  The lacing was also very impressive.  Hops are very abundant in the nose and taste.  The hops and malt were married very well.  Avery enjoyable beer overall, which hid the alcohol very well.  This was a really delicious IPA, which has everything going for it!

Nice Tan head, carbonation is medium.  The beer itself is a hazy amber color.  The aroma definitely tells you that this beer is going to focus on the hops, I get notes of apricot and a pungent hoppiness.  The apricot is the strongest aroma component, I like it.  The apricot translates to the taste of the beer, it adds a bit of a fruity backdrop that interacts with the fruitiness from the ale yeast.  A nice hop bit in the finish, followed by a clinging bitterness as a reminder of the beer that was just on my tongue.  This is a nice IPA, not as extreme as some but I really like the flavor and aroma that is packed into this beer.

Nice orange brown color with nice white head and nice lacing.  Aroma is citrus all the way, grapefruits mainly.  Flavor is very refreshing.  Hops, citrus and floral plus a decent amout of sweetness.  Really like this IPA, everyting is in balance.
This is a smooth tasting Indian Pale Ale. Hoppy, malty, and slightly bitter flavor.  Finishes clean, crisp, and dry.

Color is a pale deep orangeish yellow with a light brown tone to it, chill haze present, head just over a finger high, loosly thick and bubbly, cream colored, fades fairly quick and lace sticks well in thin webby spots and thin whispy sheets. Smell is quite a nice hop nose, sweeter pine sense thats bitterly smooth, a touch floral and spiced over a nice toasty caramel malt backbone. Taste is lovely, smooth, soft and rounded, balanced well, nothing overwhelming in the hops, bitterness in check by alot, but whats there is loaded full with nice soft sweet pine, some fresh floral hop hints, caramel malts dotted in the backing thats soft as well. the softness really stands out favorably, I liked it alot. I'm betting its a dried and fresh hop ale variant. Not such a 'in your face' IPA, a simple & welcome surprise and something I find now having had a few Alesmith brews that is something in character that seems to stand out for me in their brews. Feel is soft and pleasant, nearly full, super smooth, nothing harsh here, lingering of bitterness is shorter then most but seems to fit with this one. A bit tamer then the Yulesmith, but nearly the same in every aspect of softness and drinkablity. The softness makes for very easy drinkin'! The bomber was gone in no time. Definately an IPA to keep around for any Ol' time.

UPDATED: DEC 18, 2006 This beer pours with a golden orange body topped by a medium thick off-white head with a good amount of lacing left on the glass.  A slightly sweet and grapefruity hop aroma fills the nose followed by a slight bitterness and subtle notes of pine.  The flavor is slightly sweet yet bitter and grapefruity from hops.  A touch of pine is also observed and the finish is bitter, piney and hoppy.  Medium bodied and smooth yet slightly dry.

UPDATED: JUN 4, 2012 Finally, here it is...beer #700, and the IPA ive been waiting for! Darker amber colour with a perfect off-white dense head. An amazing looking beer. Very nice smells of hops, grapefruity and piney...but very pleasant and mouth-watering! Medium-bodied; Strong hoppy flavour (showing largely pine characteristics) balanced well with malt. Slightly sweet, but also showing alcoholic notes. Aftertaste displays a strong citrus qualities as well as a flavourful malt to balance out the hops. Overall, this was exactly what I was expecting from a very highly ranked IPA. There was nothing wrong at all with this beer, and only a great all-around experience. I wish I could get this beer more regularly, but I have to sincerely thank Rodolito for picking this up and sending it out to me...Thanks again Dave!

This was the headless Ale Smith of Sleepy Hollow! The appearance was a deep bronze color, with rich hues of amber. This IPA has an enormous pine / spruce aroma and flavor, caramel additions as well as a shock of bittering IBU’s. This beer does not contain notes of Grapefruit but it freaking plays a symphony of it, huge citric presence with big maltyness to help the balance. This brew has the feel of cask aging, although it never was. Good beer but a bit over the top for the standard IPA. I would actually compare this IPA to a barley wine, with many similar distinguishing factors.

Had Old Numskull, IPA and X all together in one sitting - sorta blending into one beer for me. Remember this closely resembling the Numbskull in looks and aroma - and taste as well. Hops were over the top!. Mouthfeel was terrific - seemingly light on texture, but hammered the palate at the same time. When caramel malt and citrus/floral hops combine like this, as with the Numbskull, I am reminded of Earl Grey tea for some reason. Nice sampling of Alesmiths - can't wait to try to Speedway!!!

First impression: aroma similar to arrogant bastard. Taste too, yet not as aggressive. The bitterness doesn't linger on tongue as long. Aroma is piney and slightly citrusy. Palate is awesome. Real tight carbonation, smooth, rich. Aftertaste is pretty slight. Only a fresh, piney hop taste lingers a bit. I enjoyed the 7.2 alc percentage. It added nice warmth halfway through the 22 ozer. Drink this beer. Long live IPA's.

Wow, this is a top-shelf IPA.  Decent head but tons of lacing, even in the bottle.  Beautful, almost clear light auburn color.  Mouthfeel is incredible, smooth and velvety.  The hops are there ale the way through.  Lovely hoppy floral aroma, great piney/citrus flavor, with a crisp hop finish.  Outstanding ale!!
Clear and bright golden. Awesome aroma - fresh, hoppy and yeasty. Smoothly carbonated. Great malt flavors - chewy-sweet cookie dough. Nice balance and sharply tasty.

Brilliant copper colored beer, topped by a vanilla colored head that lasts an exceptionally long time. After the head fades to a thick rocky layer of foam, a sweet floral aroma becomes more evident. Very nice aroma. Wow, the taste is truly phenomenal, with a combination of malty sweetness, and hops so strong they seem to be both sweet and bitter all at once. Then comes the finish. The flavors seem to completely vanish, but then a slight piney bitterness is noticed lurking around, dragging a wisp of sweetness around with it. Mouthfeel is very solid, and this beer seems to just slide down the throat.

UPDATED: SEP 27, 2003 22oz bottle  Pours a light amber with copper edges. Clarity is quite good, with lots of little bubbles from the carbonation. It's light tan head is around an inch thick and fades a bit in the middle, leaving huge clumps. Adding the yeast sediment darkens the brew considerably and leaves large chunks in the bottom of my glass. Phenomenol lacing of the glass.  Hoppy as all hell with a huge fruitiness. The one fruit that stands out the most to me is apricots...the aroma just screams apricots! There's a touch of malt underneath that is both mildly sweet and bready. Hint of vanilla... Great aroma!  Full flavored with tons of hop goodness! There's a nice malt background, but this one is all about the hops. Lots of pine, citrus, and fruit flavors meld together perfectly in one of the best IPA's I've ever encountered. There's a touch of an alcohol taste, but it stays in the background where it belongs. Adding the yeast sediment adds another dimension to the already great flavor.  Medium in body with a soft mouthfeel that thickens towards the bottom of the bottle. The yeast yields a creamier, more rounded feel on the palate. Gotta love that bottle-conditioning!  A world-class IPA.

Loved the nice thick copper color, with off white head.  Good solid floral aroma.  Nice solid hoppy bite up front with a clean creamy finish.  Good texute, with citrus and apricot hints.  This is a great IPA!

Golden hue with a nice thick white head and excellent lacing. Aroma is a major resin hop rush but was able to detect some buttery and malty notes too. The taste was smoother than expected, very balanced between the hops and malts. Nice fruity undertone. The finish is woody dry and bitter, has expected. The mouthfeel is lively as not as metallic, again a surprise. Overall, not the massive bitter, hop monster IPA I thought it may be, instead I found a nicely balance and smooth IPA worthy of high praise. Very recommended.

Sweet, grassy hops in the aroma, along with notes of honey.  Murky orange in color with yellow edges, cream colored head.  The beer had a nice maltiness to it....not typical for something from the west coast....very good, easy to drink.

What an about face after drinking Fantome. Opens the eyes to the diversity of styles and how each can be great. Pioney hops to please the "heads" and sweet malt to ease the ride. While I was rather expecting to be bowled over somehow, this was very nice and could imagine drinking all night despite the strength - if only I could find more easily.

Hazy amber with an absolutely ridiculous head.  Like a typical west coast IPA but the key difference was a very mellow finish.  I honestly don't get all the exotic stuff in the commerical description but the extreme hops and non-edgy end carry this for me as a decent brew.
a very par/sub-par ipa, not really worth the 4 rating, not really impressing at all
Solid aroma of hops and sweetness. Well balanced bitterness. Taste is sweet, hoppy, and smooth. Another great Alesmith  beer!

Cloudy appearance and fizzy with tiny, tiny bubbles.  Creamy, rocky textured head.  Popcorn butter smell.  Hopped out goodness.  Slight lemon and citrus flavors, much like grapefruit -- straight up grapefruit.  Fresh bitter feel.  Somewhere there is lurking an oaken barrel flavor.

Not as wonderful as expected, I still enjoyed this Hophead's dream come true.  Massive hops is never matched properly by the malts, although the hops alone are top-quality enough to earn a very nce rating among it's peers.  The alcohol is very present, but the hops starts AND finishes bitter and citric as the dominant factor.  No hophead should miss this, but more malt would be welcomed. Thanks to Bierbauch for this bottle!
Not as balanced as some IPA's, this is in the hop monster category, but not the worst offender I've tried. I prefer the yulesmith as far as balance goes...still a pretty nice beer though.

Pretty decent attempt in a field with some great competition.  Golden hue with good lace.  Of course, pine and citus dominate with a fairly decent malt backgound.  Not the best...not the worst.  It works.

Beautiful golden amber hue.  Pale sticky beige head.  Big fruity citrus nose, with faint pine notes and a slight vanilla background, as the description says.  Sweet with pale malts first, medium body, slightly oily, big citrus, herbal piney finish.  Very nice, Im impressed.
Too over-the-top for me.  Intensely bitter and citric with no real balance.  Good cascade aroma, but that's about all.

The carbonation in this IPA is borderline ridiculous!  Upon the pour, a frothy, very thick white head develops, and active carbonation is visible in the clear amber body.  Aroma is floral, spicy hops.  Flavor has a distinct hops bite, but sweet malts provide the backbone, and I must admit the overall package is one smooth drink.  Looking over my ratings, I am surprised to find so many good IPAs, and this one stacks up with Stone's IPA, slightly below Bells Two-Hearted Ale, and doesn't quite reach the levels attained by my two favorites, Dogfish Head 90 Minute and Three Floyds Dreadnaught.  Here's to cracking that Speedway Stout...rating 200 can't come fast enough!
UPDATED: JUN 21, 2013 A decent IPA with a floral, foamy head smell.   One of my all time favorite IPAs

Big, white head, rocky, sticky. Bright copper hue. Large citrusy, piney nose! Med/full body brew. Lots of hops!, sweet resiney hops! Malt plays a small part in the flavor deptartment bit is more noticeable as it warms, as is the alc. flavor and aroma. INTENSE hop aromas and flavors! I like it! Damn nice IPA!

Nice golden orange color.  Foamy head with very small bubbles.  Deep aroma of hops and fruitiness.  Nice IPA with a good balance of frutiness and bitterness. A good little bite at the end. An  excellent contribution by Alesmith here.
Bottle: WOW what a beer. Citrusy, orange & grapefruit, with carmel/molasses. Golden orange color. A carmel nectar. Sweet and bitter. Long bitter creamy finish. WOW what a beer
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: UPDATED: JUL 9, 2003 Excellent use of the wonderful.  All of us hopheads could do much worse than drinking this very good IPA.  Wonderful hoppy piney aroma.  Looks good in the glass, pours large fluffy head which stays throughout.  Heavy lacing.  Nice amber color.  Nice hoppy flavor.  May be some malt in there somewhere, but hard to spot through the hops.  Very good IPA.
UPDATED: NOV 12, 2004 A fine beer from a bunch of good guys at Alesmith. Although I prefer double IPAs, this offering is suitable for just about anything. Give it a try.

UPDATED: SEP 24, 2004 Nice head!  Very nice IPA.  I like Stone ruination and Victory Hopdevil better, but this one isn't too far behind.  Victory is better balanced and smoother, while Ruination is tastes similar to this but is a bit more  refined and clean.  rerate 092404:  I'm really loving this right now.  I've been getting tired of IPAs with hops and nothing else.  I had a growler of Pure Hoppiness the other day, and I just wasn't into it.  The Alesmith IPA has a little malty swetness that just adds to it.  It has a very soft palate with some chalkiness to it.  It also has an excellnt tart, dark cherry aftertaste that lingers in underneath and in the back of the tongue.  I bumped it up a point in overall score

Golden sunshine radiates from my glass, thin cloud whisps form sun rays that pierce right down to the soul. . . Pine cones and huge hop leaves stimey my sense of smell, but caress it just the same. . . Flavours are more mild than I would have thought with such a large nose - some nice caramel, bits of pine needles, and hoppy bitterness.   A wonderfully clean palate makes this a huge pleasure to drink.

Pours a light, golden color with light, fluffy white head that quickly dropped to a nice, white ring with plenty of lace.  The aroma is has a light grain and caramel aroma seeping through intense pine cones and orange and grapefruit rind.  Very bitter, with plenty of hop flavor and tongue-puckering strength.  With all of the bitterness, it also has a pretty nice malt balance.  Hop resin, bitter citrus fruit and fresh green plant matter lay atop caramel chews and whole grains.  A very enjoyable beer experience, even if a little too slanted toward the bitterness.

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2010 This dry IPAs straw subtleties thrive in an orange-laden resinous hopglade, reverberating on fresh and vibrant grass blades...Utterly beautiful, this refined hop signature should be canonized...Bold yet classy, biting yet refreshing and quaffable, this effervescent hop elixir is at once obscene and purifying...

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2003 This is an outstanding IPA! The freshness of this ale knocked me off my feet as if I were drinking it at the brewery right out of the tank. A beautiful coppery color body and a beige colored head looked beautiful resting in my glass. The aroma of a piney hoppiness hit my nose as soon as I raised my glass. And the flavor was unbelievable. I can only remember one other time I had such an outstandig ale and that was in a brewpub in Boston many years ago. Wow I can't wait to have another!!!
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: Copper color with a thin oily head.  Some laceing on the glass with atolls of of dense bubbles in the diminishing beigh froth.  American hoopieness and toasted toffee in the nose.  Bitterness greets you up front but is not overbearing, resinouse and orangy tempered by a nice caramel malty aspect with touches of mellon and mint.  Bitter and sweet blend exellently in this brew, its a shame it taken me so long to try this one.  Finishes with a lingering piney bitterness and some grainy malts.

Pours with an amber color and a moderate head. Nice hoppy aroma. A fairly full bodied beer. Starts with a nice malt flavor followed by a wave of hops. I enjoyed this beer and if given the opportunity would certainly buy it again.

Medium brown color. Medium head. Aroma is hops, juicy, grapefruity and floral. A medium bodied IPA. Malts are nutty and sweet. But this is a hopfest of a beer: piney and resiny, citrusy and grapefruity, floral and spicy. Hoppy without being too bitter. Nicely balanced. Very smooth. Hides the 7.25% alcohol very well. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is bitter.

Strong, pungent aroma of fresh hops.  Light amber color with a frothy white head.  Flavor is dominated by hops - citrusy, grassy and spicy combined.  Barely detectable malt flavor underneath the hops.  Finish is on the dry side, and a sunstantial bitterness lingers long on the back of the tongue.  A very good IPA, however there is definitely another tier of IPAs above this one.

UPDATED: FEB 25, 2015 Super soft on the palate, melts in your mouth. Balanced between its creamy caramel malts, bread notes and subtle citrus, with hops that lay way back behind it all and then finish strong with notes of pine and cedar. As soft and balanced as an IPA gets. (Defeated Ballast Point Sculpin and Stone IPA in a blind tasting after the fact).

My new favorite IPA. A lesson in brewing. Others who want to make an IPA take note; big hopes makes a good IPA, big hops with a solid malt backbone makes a great IPA. The movement from resiny hops to a sweet malt flavor with hints of fruity esters makes this a terrific IPA.

Glowing orange hued with a thin lacey head.  Bountiful hop aroma as if I just poured pure hop extract.  Body is moderately thick, lightly effervescent and finishes dry and citrusy. Smooth with an almost syrupy mouthfeel which improves as it warms.  Could be a little sweeter and more balanced.  A pretty good IPA, but it is still a step behind Stone.

Nice head with a hazy amber appearance.  Very strong bitter hop aroma with extreme piney notes, noticeably lacking a lot of citrus character.  Very dry finish and palate overall for the matter, little residual sweetness.  Decent composition, but not as good as the Stone IPA in my opinion.  Bitterness emphasized.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2003 Bottled:  Light amber coloured. Medium head. Has fruitcharacters in the nose. Hops and cocoa as well. Flavour is hoppy and has cocoa characters. Is medium bitter in the end. Thanks to herbjones for this great IPA.

I like Alesmith, I really do.  The make the best ESB (Anvil) that I've ever had.  

This beer just doesn't do it for me.  A lot of head, the hops are more like and English IPA than a California one.  Pales in comparison to Ruination IPA, IMHO.

Very large foamy head. I mean very large. Nice hoppy aroma and a bold mouthful, creating a very good well balanced American version of IPA.  Sweet enough to offset the bitter finish, getting better as the glass warms. Quite enjoyable.

Tasted on tap at the Alesmith brewery. This one poured a moderate to dark gold with lively carbonation and mild yet nicely thick and creamy white to ever so slightly tannish head. Aroma's of citrus and pine absolutely overwhelmed my nose and woke me up for another round. The taste is extremely fresh and piney. I have to agree with Peter that these are indeed some of the freshest hops around. Some malt is thrown in near the end to balance it out mildly, but this is highly skewed toward a palate ass kicking in the form of citrusy assaults!!! A nice floral ending and a good treat from the tap.

One of my favorite IPA's. Hoppy and well balanced malt flavor. Poured a clear dark gold with a thick, fluffy, off-white head that was almost merangue-like. The head gradually subsided but left a moderate amount of lacing. Intense, rich floral hoppy aroma with citrus and pine. Hoppy grapefruit flavor with bitterness and smooth maltiness. A bitter aftertaste with a small amount of malt sweetness. A moderate mouthfeel and medium carbonation with a slight creaminess.
Looks nice, smells good, has a nice mouth feel, but is a bit too bitter for my tastes - a tad too much on the hops side. Nonetheless, a good IPA

medium copper color with a nice thin white head. aroma is big on pine with a little citrus and a very very slight sweetness to it. flavor is of pine with some grapefruit with a bit of alcohol in the aftertaste. excellent IPA..thanks to the silky one

My bottle had an issue...lots of floaties...it looked nasty. The flavor did not seem to be too screwed up...very fruity aroma and a strong flavor with fruits an hops...it was a bit more bitter at the end. I will re-rate again when I feel that I had a better bottle. But...I don"t think it was too bad considering.

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2007 6/1/2002:  Citrusy, nice hop bitternes. Good tasting IPA. Kinda grapefruit like after taste. 

Re-rate 12/15/02:   Picked up a jug at the brewery. Had to kick it up a point, even better than bottle.

Re-rate 3/28/03:   Fresh from the [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ Pours a cloudy copper color with a medium fluffy white head. 2/6/04: The [email protected]/* <![CDATA[ */!function(t,e,r,n,c,a,p){try{t=document.currentScript||function(){for(t=document.getElementsByTagName('script'),e=t.length;e--;)if(t[e].getAttribute('data-cfhash'))return t[e]}();if(t&&(c=t.previousSibling)){p=t.parentNode;if(a=c.getAttribute('data-cfemail')){for(e='',r='0x'+a.substr(0,2)|0,n=2;a.length-n;n+=2)e+='%'+('0'+('0x'+a.substr(n,2)^r).toString(16)).slice(-2);p.replaceChild(document.createTextNode(decodeURIComponent(e)),c)}p.removeChild(t)}}catch(u){}}()/* ]]> */ cant leave well enough alone, theyve been tweeking the formula...all for the better...this IPA ROCKS!!!  

3/25/04 Kick it up a notch. Peter, Tod  and Matt have fine tuned this one to the max. Quit while youre ahead guys, this is about as good as it gets !!!

UPDATED: JUN 10, 2004 Pours with good head.  Light gold and cloudy in appearance.  A citrus aroma had dominate present.  The taste of pine and citrus is easily to pick-up.  Nicely hopped, it is one of the best IPAs I've had.  Thank you jcalabre for this very fine brew. 
Had it again on 3-21-03 and the only thing different about is Thanks Herbjones!!

UPDATED: JAN 18, 2003 Beautiful orangish-yellow color. Big head. Apricots and grapefruit in the nose. A little piney. Definitely some west cost hops in this one. Some malt. Nice medium body. Fairly bitter. I think I either had this too warm or the bottle was a little past its prime. The strong apricot flavor was a little disconcerting. Otherwise, a tasty beer...2nd bottle: Same impression as the first bottle, only this time my glass was filled with giant clumps of yeast even after a careful pour. The two bottles I"ve rated were bought by different people and the second one was well-stored, eliminating my suspicions that my first tasting was skewed by a bad bottle. I can"t believe this is rated at 4.13 (as of 11/24/02). Way overrated in my opinion. Not a bad beer but no way is this a top 50 beer. Better IPA than Two Hearted? No friggin" way!

UPDATED: APR 28, 2005 pours a cloudy apricot glazed amber with a quickly disappearing head..The aroma was extremely piney and had strong notes of wet freshly cut grass, grapefruit...starts with a nice balanced bitter grapefruit flavor, showing subtle piney notes but remaining quite balanced.  I used to think this beer was more over the top, but its surprisingly balanced..maybe a tad bit too much...maybe....Alcohol is completely hidden though...and its not as sticky as some IPAs can be.

Ooops! Lots of yeast in the pour. Better luck next time.
The aroma is quite malty and very hoppy. Perfume and dried, fuzzy fruits in the nose.
Hazy dark golden color with large bits of yeast. The medium-sized head is white, creamy and fully lasting. Excellent lacing.
The flavor is very malty up front. Toffee and caramel. Very nicely unsweetened by the hops on the backside. A very warming, complexly bitter flavor. Hops and  fuzzy fruits. Full-bodied. Lively carbonation and a creamy mouthfeel. A long, nicely bitter, dry finish. Excellent IPA. HopHead ambrosia. Thanks go out to herbjones for this one. I just burped up a hop blossom.

UPDATED: OCT 17, 2013 Bottle. Head is initially average sized, frothy, off-white, mostly lasting. Body is light amber. Aroma is lightly malty (grain), moderately hoppy (pine/resin, grapefruit), moderately yeasty (dough), with a note of detergent/dishrag. Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, lightly to moderately bitter. Finish is lightly sweet, moderately acidic, moderately to heavily bitter, unclean. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation, lightly astringent.  Alesmith is no longer Alesmith.  Its that simple.  The beer quality has fallen so far that this is a new brewery.  Sour and dirty, just like Alesmith fans must want their IPAs to be.  Sigh.

UPDATED: JAN 26, 2003 Citrus-pine aroma, man this is one for the hopheads, amber-yellow color with alot of yeast floating around, very hoppy yet balanced as well, man this is one hell of an IPA, so for I really like this brewery.
I thank herbjones for this killer brew.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2005 Great beer. Need I actually say how great alesmith is. So many different flavors, it would not do it justice to try to describe them all. ALls i can say is that this is a damn fine brew from a damn fine brewery.

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2003 Re-Rate:Still delightful just not as classy tasting as first time.Not much older either.FRESH bottle. Poured a huge milkey,pillowy,creamy head.It is so clingy it leaves artwork in your glass.Aroma is so ridiculous you create mental pictures of beatifully crystally hops.Also has a nice subtle toasted malt aroma.Wonderful balance and bitterness.Flavors of crisp hop orange,melon, and lemony flavors.The finish is extremely crisp and leafy.

This beer cant get top honors in appearance. While the cloudy amber body is excellent, the head is slow to form and fades rather quickly. For the style, Ive come to expect  big, lasting heads. The thin bitter hops are truly balanced by the nice big biscuity malt. Some IPAs have a complex hop flavor where theyre more than just bitter, but the profile on this one leans more towards the bitter with subtle  piney and malty citric notes. The pine gets stronger as the beer warms. I also picked up a nice organge fruit flavor as well that made this a pretty good beer.

UPDATED: JUL 5, 2006 (Re-rate) I had to share a bottle the first time and I didnt take proper tasting notes, so here we go. A slightly hazy deep golden. Sticky, compact head that lasts until the end. Huge nose of orange slices blanketed with pine needles. Huge hop profile, piney, resiny hop burps commence immediately, orange zest, slightly sweet pale malt rides in the back seat smacking the leafy hops in the back of the head if they go too fast. Medium bodied, smooth, slightly warming and drying at the end. A damn fine IPA and one to seek out if you love the style.

Unfortunately, I drank this IPA rather warm so I may have missed some flavors.  Citrus grapefruit permeates, like the pink grapefruit that you can drink when you stop at the Florida grapefruit stands.  Alesmith can do no wrong.

The cask conditioned version of this beer is miraculous The Hop Flavor is immense but balances well with Maltiness  This beer is off the scale
a world class beer

Lovely gold color with suspended sediment (lots of character).  Kickass sweet, herbal, hoppy aroma (ooooooooooh the anticipation!).  Theres grapefruit in both the aroma and the flavor.  It has a bite that builds from mildly hoppy to bitter, and a pure hop finish.  YUM!!

A very nice grapefruit and lemon rind aroma beginning segues into a very smooth, wait is this an IPA? I said smooth, damn. This is subtle and sophisticated IPA. This beer pours bright gold and brims with lace that would make a Belgian doily blush. Yet, there is plenty of good hops in here. It starts out very creamy and bitey, then fades away. This is not as big as some of the hop monsters out there these days, but deserve kudos for being a finely balance, well crafted IPA.
Hazy orange color.  Citrusy hop aroma and flavors, in fact there isnt much more than hops in here, somewhat unbalanced if you ask me.
Unusual but plesant gin-like junipery aroma, with a hint of citrusy Cascade smell.  Aromatic citusy bitter tea flavor.  Very clean mouthfeel for the style.  Too bad my tasting glass only held 4oz.
much like the X, never quite lives up to the promise of its beautiful nose.  good, but could have been great

UPDATED: SEP 1, 2003 Sparkling deep golden color and radiant PNW aroma of pine with some juniper. I was happy the bready malt flavors stayed subdued enough to enjoy a long bitter and eliminate any comparison to a barley wine that some of the big IPAs (DFH) now are causing. The taste is remarkably clean with a long citrusy bitter finish and a hint of mint. This one's a big winner.

Slightly hazy, copper color, silky head of foam. 

Great fragrant hoppy aroma, fresh lemon and grapefruit, slightly metallic. Alcohol presence. Touch of sweet fruit. 

Tantalizing carbonation and slight sharpness but essentially smooth for its genre. Hop fruit prevalent throughout, but especially so in grapefruit bitter finish. Reminds me very much of an English cask IPA even if it is much more bitter.
Very dry, hoppy with a pine aroma.  Nice IPA but not as much flavor or aroma as Ruination or Dogfish 90 minute.
Bronze; big cascade nose; very citrusy (grapefruit) - pure hop juice with a dry finish.  A pleasing drink.
Unfiltered golden, bit of head.  Aroma is Cascade City!  Sweet cascade flavor, good body that holds throughout.  Not much balance, but you dont really miss it.
High, sweet and soft pleasing aroma. Hopy, parfumy which was ok but is it the best IPA out there?
Hazy golden colored with a creamy white head. Nice up front hoppy taste w/ a clean finish. A very nice IPA

A completely different animal than the Indica. Hop/pine resin aroma practically floats across the kitchen, accosting everything in its path. Nicely light tan in color, very evident hop & yeast? particulate. Has that creamy in-mouth feel that the major hop-monsters from Stone and Bear Rep. have. Very strong, muscled beer, but it goes down easy. Not nearly as much caramel malt as in the Indica, or some others, but still quite a treat.
user_location: Łódż, Warsaw, Poland; Michigan, Ohio, USA

text: Poured the color of honey with a thin head that seemed to stick around as a thin lace on top. Aroma of hops and citrus.Palate is smooth with tiny bubbles and just enough body. First flavor is hops followed quickly by a little citrus tinge. Malt bringing up the rear balancing everything out. Ends crisp and clean. This is a great IPA! IPAs are not my fave style because lately it seems everyone just wants to out hop each other. Nice to find one that does not feel the need to go over the top just for the sake of it.

This beer pours with a nice creamy head. It has a solid herbal, with hints of citrus, aroma. The palate detects a hefty hop presence, bitterness from which the tongue searches for relief. Enough malt is present to provide a balance. But overall, too much hop for my allergies to grasses, etc. But I wont hold it against the beer. For all you hopheads, this is a winner!
WOW.  Wondeful hop aroma.  Big hop bitterness balanced very nicely in the body.  An excellent IPA.  Definitely one of the best.

UPDATED: JAN 7, 2004 Huge hops aroma, and I mean huge.  There are chunks of hops floating along with the yeast.  The taste could easy overpower and kill a non-hop-head.  The best part is that I feel that I'm drinking beer and not just hops juice. I think this is hoppier than 90 Minute IPA or Stone 5th. I'll be back to this one.  Thanks Gusler!

Excellent hop aroma.  Also great hop bite but the mouthfeel leaves me wondering what the beer is missing.  That is my only problem with it though.  It is definitely worth a try and i will drink it again.

UPDATED: JUN 18, 2005 Post-Skip version: Overly husky malt flavors, unpronounced/sloppy hop flavors, and overly yeasty aroma and flavors. Not sure where the brightness has gone, as this was once teeming with bright, glorious hop flavors and aromas. This isnt what it once was, although Im told the recipe hasnt changed.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: Vintage 2002: I really think it should have its own, but this will do. Pours a deep somewhat cloudy amber, frothy white head and sheets of lace. Nose is Hop floral, malt and a tad citrus, lots of goodies floating around in the bottle, Hops or Yeast?, good no matter which. Malt front, medium to full top, finish is All Hops, this is an IPA Lovers IPA,, and not meant for the Palate Challenged. Another Beautiful Beer, from my most favorite brewery. Trust me on this one if your a Hop Head, this is a must try, the hops just keeps comming back and back.
